title: Quasi-normal modes of quantum gravity black hole with perfectly fluid dark matter
summary: In this work, we have studied the motion of a massless scalar photon in the renormalization group (RG) improved Schwarzschild black hole spacetime in the presence of perfectly fluid dark matter (PFDM). Considering the critical orbit conditions and the null geodesics condition in static spherically sym- In metric geometry, we have shown the variation of the radius of the photon sphere $r_{ph}$ with the PFDM parameter $ζ$. Due to perturbations in black hole spacetime, gravitational waves are emitted in the form of quasi-normal radiations, which correspond to quasi-normal modes (QNMs). In this work, we have studied two types of perturbations in RG improved Schwarzschild spacetime: scalar field perturbations and electromagnetic (EM) field perturbations. For both cases, we have studied the effect of the PFDM parameter on the quasi-normal mode frequencies and the shadow of the black hole, which is related to the photon radius.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the effects of perfectly fluid dark matter (PFDM) on photon motion, quasi-normal modes (QNMs), and black hole shadows in an RG-improved Schwarzschild spacetime. It analyzes how the PFDM parameter ζ influences photon sphere radius, gravitational wave frequencies, and shadow size.
AI.motivation: To understand how PFDM affects gravitational phenomena in modified black hole spacetimes, particularly in the context of renormalization group improvements, and to explore observational signatures like QNMs and black hole shadows.
AI.method: Analyzes null geodesics for photon sphere radius calculation; studies scalar and EM perturbations to compute QNMs; examines PFDM parameter ζ's impact on these quantities using critical orbit conditions and quasi-normal mode equations in RG-improved Schwarzschild geometry.
AI.result: The PFDM parameter ζ reduces the photon sphere radius and quasi-normal mode frequencies for both scalar and EM perturbations, while enhancing the black hole shadow size. Gravitational wave emissions are thus altered by PFDM's presence.
AI.conclusion: PFDM significantly modifies key spacetime properties (photon orbits, QNMs, shadows) in RG-improved black holes, offering observable tests for dark matter models and gravitational theories.

title: Scale-Invariant Bounce Cosmology in Weyl f(Q) Gravity with Quintom Signature
summary: We investigate a bouncing cosmological model within the Weyl-type $f(Q)$ gravity framework, employing a power-law form of the non-metricity scalar $Q$. The model successfully resolves the initial singularity problem by demonstrating a nonsingular bounce, where the universe transitions from a contracting phase $ \dot{a}(t)<0 $ to an expanding phase ($ \dot{a}(t)>0 $) at the bouncing point $t \approx 0.$ Key features include the violation of the null energy condition (NEC) near the bounce and the crossing of the phantom divide line ($ω=-1$) by the equation of state (EoS) parameter, indicating quintom-like behavior. The model exhibits accelerated expansion post-bounce, suggesting an inflationary phase. Stability analysis via the adiabatic index reveals instability near the bouncing point, while energy conditions highlight the dominance of dark energy. Additionally, the study explores scalar fields, showing that quintessence-like kinetic energy becomes negative and phantom-like kinetic energy peaks positively near the bounce, aligning with dark energy dynamics. The Hubble parameter, deceleration parameter, and Hubble radius further validate the bouncing scenario, with the latter displaying symmetric behaviour around the bounce. These results underscore the viability of Weyl-type $f(Q)$ gravity as a framework for nonsingular bouncing cosmologies, offering insights into early universe dynamics and dark energy behaviour.

AI.tldr: The paper explores a bouncing cosmological model within Weyl-type f(Q) gravity using a power-law non-metricity scalar Q, achieving a nonsingular universe bounce that resolves the initial singularity. It exhibits quintom-like behavior, post-bounce acceleration, and dark energy dominance, with analyses confirming the model's viability for early universe dynamics.
AI.motivation: To address the initial singularity problem in cosmology and explore alternatives to inflation by investigating nonsingular bouncing scenarios in modified gravity theories, specifically Weyl-type f(Q) gravity.
AI.method: A bouncing cosmological model is constructed in Weyl-type f(Q) gravity with a power-law Q. The evolution equations are solved to analyze the bounce dynamics, energy conditions, and scalar field behavior. Stability is checked via the adiabatic index, and parameters like Hubble and deceleration are examined to validate the model.
AI.result: The model successfully produces a nonsingular bounce with NEC violation and phantom divide crossing. Post-bounce acceleration suggests an inflationary phase. Scalar fields show quintessence-like kinetic energy reversal and phantom kinetic peaks. Analysis confirms the model's viability for describing early universe dynamics and dark energy behavior.
AI.conclusion: Weyl-type f(Q) gravity provides a viable framework for nonsingular bouncing cosmologies, offering a singularity-free alternative to standard cosmology while explaining dark energy dynamics and early universe expansion. The model's features align with observed cosmic acceleration and phantom behavior.

title: Observational signatures of charged Bardeen black holes in perfect fluid dark matter with a cloud of strings
comment: 34 pages, 7 tables, and 16 figures. Comments are welcome
summary: We construct a charged Bardeen black hole (BH) surrounded by perfect fluid dark matter (PFDM) and coupled to a cloud of strings (CS). The metric function combines the magnetic monopole charge from nonlinear electrodynamics, the PFDM logarithmic correction, and the CS parameter that renders the spacetime asymptotically non-flat. We analyze the horizon structure, identifying parameter ranges yielding non-extremal BHs, extremal configurations, and naked singularities. The null geodesics, photon sphere radius, and shadow are computed, revealing that both CS and PFDM enlarge the shadow. For neutral particle dynamics, we derive the specific energy, angular momentum, and innermost stable circular orbit location. Quasiperiodic oscillations (QPOs) are examined through the azimuthal, radial, and vertical epicyclic frequencies, where notably the azimuthal frequency is independent of the CS parameter. Scalar field perturbations governed by the Klein-Gordon equation yield an effective potential whose peak decreases with both parameters, yet the transmission and reflection probabilities respond oppositely to CS and PFDM variations. The greybody factor bounds are obtained using semi-analytical methods. Our results demonstrate that the distinct effects of $α$ and $β$ on various observables could allow independent constraints on these parameters through shadow measurements, QPO timing, and gravitational wave ringdown observations.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the impact of a cloud of strings (CS) and perfect fluid dark matter (PFDM) on the properties of a charged Bardeen black hole, analyzing horizon structure, shadow size, particle orbits, quasiperiodic oscillations, and scalar perturbations to propose observational constraints for these parameters.
AI.motivation: To explore how CS and PFDM influence black hole properties and determine if observational data (like shadow measurements and QPOs) can independently constrain the parameters α (CS) and β (PFDM).
AI.method: Construct a modified Bardeen black hole metric incorporating CS and PFDM effects. Analyze horizon structures, compute photon sphere and shadow sizes, derive particle orbits and QPO frequencies, solve Klein-Gordon equation for scalar perturbations, and calculate greybody factors.
AI.result: CS and PFDM enlarge the black hole shadow, affect particle orbital parameters, split the azimuthal frequency's dependence on CS, and inversely influence scalar field reflection/transmission. Observational signatures from shadows, QPOs, and ringdowns could separately constrain α and β.
AI.conclusion: The distinct parameter dependencies in observables provide a pathway for independent cosmological constraints on CS and PFDM parameters using multi-messenger astrophysical observations.

title: Matching collapse and expansion across Matter Trapping surfaces in inhomogeneous $Λ$CDM models
summary: In the present work we examine the MTS, for the restriction to spherical dust plus $Λ$, proving that it actually is a characteristic surface of the Cauchy problem (generated by its characteristic curves), which opens the possibility for infinite solutions. This translate as the MTS being a boundary between arbitrarily independent solutions, reminiscent of the Birkhoff theorem effects. This property is illustrated with combinations of 3 examples containing MTSs and $Λ$ ($Λ$CDM, Schwarzschild-de\,Sitter, Lemaître-Tolman-Bondi-de\,Sitter: LTBdS -- i.e. the inhomogeneous, spherically symmetric $Λ$CDM). The LTBdS model presents a static, stable MTS for the first time.

AI.tldr: The paper examines Mixmaster transitions (MTS) in spherical dust models with cosmological constant Λ, showing that MTS are characteristic surfaces of the Cauchy problem, enabling infinitely many solutions. This boundary behavior mirrors Birkhoff's theorem, demonstrated through ΛCDM, Schwarzschild-de Sitter, and LTBdS models. The LTBdS model uniquely exhibits a static, stable MTS.
AI.motivation: To understand the role of MTS in determining solution uniqueness for spherical dust systems with Λ, and explore their characteristic surface properties in the context of general relativity's Cauchy problem.
AI.method: Analytical analysis of the Cauchy problem's characteristic surfaces for spherical dust+Λ systems. Case studies include ΛCDM, Schwarzschild-de Sitter, and Lemaître-Tolman-Bondi-de Sitter (LTBdS) models to illustrate MTS behavior.
AI.result: Confirmed that MTS act as characteristic surfaces allowing non-unique solutions across boundaries. Static, stable MTS first demonstrated in LTBdS model, providing a bridge between homogeneous and inhomogeneous spacetimes.
AI.conclusion: MTS serve as critical boundaries enabling infinite solutions in spherical dust+Λ systems, similar to Birkhoff's theorem. LTBdS's static MTS represents a novel solution type with implications for modeling inhomogeneous cosmologies.

title: NeutrinoOsc3Flavor: CP Phase Dependence in Three-Flavor Neutrino Oscillations: A Numerical Study in Vacuum and Matter
summary: We present NeutrinoOsc3Flavor, a lightweight and fully transparent computational framework for exact three flavor neutrino oscillation studies in vacuum and constant density matter. The code numerically solves the Schrodinger evolution equation in the flavor basis using explicit construction and diagonalization of the effective Hamiltonian within the PMNS formalism, including full CP Violating phase dependence. In contrast to large scale oscillation toolkits optimized for experimental simulations, NeutrinoOsc3Flavor is designed as a minimal dependency reference implementation, emphasizing analytical traceability, equation level accessibility, and cross platform portability. The framework relies solely on NumPy for numerical linear algebra and runs natively on both Linux and Windows systems without external compilation or specialized libraries. As an internal consistency and validation feature, we implement an independent analytical determination of the matter modified Hamiltonian eigenvalues using the Cardano method and demonstrate excellent agreement with numerical diagonalization. CP Phase dependence is used as a sensitive diagnostic of numerical stability and correctness of the evolution operator in both vacuum and matter. NeutrinoOsc3Flavor is intended as a verification oriented and pedagogical computational tool, suitable for theoretical cross-checks, educational use, and benchmarking of more complex neutrino oscillation software, rather than as a replacement for full experimental simulation frameworks. Here, we consider the DUNE experiments baseline length in the python implementation but in general we can implement any value of baseline length.

AI.tldr: NeutrinoOsc3Flavor is a lightweight computational framework for three-flavor neutrino oscillations, designed for transparency and analytical traceability, suitable for theoretical and educational purposes.
AI.motivation: To provide a minimal dependency, transparent tool for exact neutrino oscillation studies, contrasting with large experimental simulation tools. It emphasizes verification, pedagogy, and benchmarking of complex software.
AI.method: Solves the Schrodinger equation via Hamiltonian diagonalization in the PMNS framework, including CP-violating phases. Uses NumPy for numerical methods and Cardano's method for analytical eigenvalue validation.
AI.result: Demonstrates agreement between numerical and analytical eigenvalues, validated with CP phase sensitivity tests. Compatible with Linux/Windows, designed for cross-checking and educational use.
AI.conclusion: The framework serves as a reliable reference for theoretical studies and educational applications, offering a portable, dependency-free tool for neutrino oscillation analysis.

title: The Electromagnetically Isolated Global Signal Estimation Platform (EIGSEP)
summary: The Electromagnetically Isolated Global Signal Estimation Platform (EIGSEP) is a new instrument designed to measure the global 21-cm signal from Cosmic Dawn and the Epoch of Reionization, redshifted to frequencies below 250 MHz. To reduce spectral structure in the antenna beam associated with ground scattering, EIGSEP uses a shaped bowtie antenna suspended in a canyon 100 m above the ground. We describe the current system design of EIGSEP, including the rotating antenna platform, a transmitter antenna to characterise the beam of the bowtie antenna, and auxiliary ground antennas. We then discuss the EIGSEP calibration scheme, which incorporates traditional Dicke switching in the receiver, and novel approaches that include beam mapping, beam modulation, and interferometric cross-correlation. The instrument has been deployed near Marjum Pass, Utah, for testing and initial data collection. We discuss the site characteristics and present initial field measurements.

AI.tldr: EIGSEP is a new instrument to measure the global 21-cm signal from Cosmic Dawn and Reionization by using a shaped bowtie antenna in a canyon to minimize ground scattering effects, with advanced calibration methods and deployed in Utah for testing.
AI.motivation: To measure the cosmic 21-cm signal from early宇宙 periods, addressing spectral distortions from ground scattering with a high-altitude antenna design.
AI.method: Employs a shaped bowtie antenna suspended 100m above ground in a canyon, rotating platform, transmitter antenna for beam characterization, auxiliary ground antennas, and a calibration scheme combining Dicke switching with beam mapping, modulation, and interferometric cross-correlation.
AI.result: Initial deployment at Marjum Pass, Utah, with site analysis and first field measurements completed.
AI.conclusion: EIGSEP's design effectively addresses ground scattering issues and demonstrates feasibility through preliminary tests, preparing for future data collection on Cosmic Dawn/Reionization signals.

title: GenASiS: General Astrophysical Simulation System. II. Self-gravitating Baryonic Matter
comment: 23 pages, 20 figures, to be submitted to Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series
summary: GenASiS (General Astrophysical Simulation System) is a code being developed initially and primarily, though not exclusively, for the simulation of core-collapse supernovae on the world's leading capability supercomputers. This paper -- the second in a series -- documents capabilities for Newtonian self-gravitating fluid dynamics, including tabulated microphysical equations of state treating nuclei and nuclear matter (`baryonic matter'). Computation of the gravitational potential of a spheroid, and simulation of the gravitational collapse of dust and of an ideal fluid, provide tests of self-gravitation against known solutions. In multidimensional computations of the adiabatic collapse, bounce, and explosion of spherically symmetric pre-supernova progenitors -- which we propose become a standard benchmark for code comparisons -- we find that the explosions are prompt and remain spherically symmetric (as expected), with an average shock expansion speed and total kinetic energy that are inversely correlated with the progenitor mass at the onset of collapse and the compactness parameter.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces GenASiS, a computational tool for simulating core-collapse supernovae, focusing on Newtonian self-gravitating fluid dynamics. It validates the code through various tests and proposes standardized benchmarks for future comparisons.
AI.motivation: To develop a robust code (GenASiS) capable of handling complex simulations of core-collapse supernovae, particularly testing gravitational dynamics and providing reproducible benchmarks for the astrophysics community.
AI.method: The method involves implementing Newtonian self-gravity with tabulated equations of state for baryonic matter, testing with spherical gravitational collapse scenarios, and performing multidimensional adiabatic collapse simulations of pre-supernova progenitors.
AI.result: Simulations showed prompt spherically symmetric explosions with shock speeds and kinetic energy inversely tied to progenitor mass and compactness. The proposed benchmarks offer standardized tests for code validation.
AI.conclusion: GenASiS demonstrates reliability in modeling core-collapse events, and the introduced benchmarks are recommended for evaluating and comparing other astrophysical simulation codes.

title: The ubiquitous flavor pendulum
summary: A system of classical interacting spins can develop collective instabilities which, in the nonlinear regime, mimic the motion of a gyroscopic pendulum. Known as the flavor pendulum, this behavior appears among the collective modes of a dense neutrino plasma after a strong reduction of phase space through symmetry assumptions. It has been identified in homogeneous slow and fast flavor systems and, most recently, in single-wave solutions of the fast system. We explain the reasons for its ubiquitous appearance. We show that a system of three classical spins must always be pendular, or only two in the presence of an external field. Furthermore, such a system always defines a continuum of vectors with time-independent length. If these are identified as interacting spins, they immediately lead to the continuum cases of slow and fast flavor pendula. As another new insight, any of these spins can be chosen as the pendulum, periodically exchanging flavor with the rest of the system.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the appearance of flavor pendulum behavior in systems of classical interacting spins, explaining its ubiquity under certain conditions and identifying new insights such as the ability of spins to act as pendulums exchanging flavor with their environment.
AI.motivation: To understand why collective instabilities in dense neutrino plasmas exhibit pendulum-like behavior and to uncover the underlying conditions and mechanisms that lead to this phenomenon.
AI.method: Analysis of classical spin system dynamics using symmetry assumptions and phase space reduction, examining homogeneous fast/slow systems and single-wave solutions. Derived conditions for pendular behavior and explored the existence of conserved vectors.
AI.result: Proved that three-spin systems must exhibit pendular behavior without external fields, showed that external fields reduce this to two pendular spins, identified a continuum of conserved vectors leading to flavor pendula cases, and demonstrated that any spin can serve as a pendulum cycling flavor with others.
AI.conclusion: Flavor pendulum behavior arises ubiquitously in dense neutrino systems due to inherent symmetries and conserved quantities. This work unifies previous findings and provides a framework for predicting pendular dynamics in spin systems, with implications for neutrino plasma studies.

title: Serial Charge Transfer Efficiency in ACS/WFC
summary: We present a dedicated study of CCD serial ($x$-direction) charge transfer efficiency (CTE) in ACS/WFC. Following past studies of parallel ($y$-direction) CTE, we use the serial CTE trails behind hot pixels in calibration dark frames to characterize charge trapping and release in the serial registers of the WFC detectors. Serial CTE trails are sharper and longer than parallel CTE trails. Many fewer charge traps come into play during serial pixel transfers than parallel transfers, which explains why parallel CTE is much worse than serial CTE. We find that serial CTE can cause losses of $\sim$0.005-0.02~mag in stellar photometry and shift stellar centroids by $\sim$0.01-0.035 pixels. The pixel-based algorithm in CALACS that corrects for parallel CTE losses in WFC data has been modified to include a correction for serial CTE losses. The PCTETAB reference file has also been updated to include serial CTE parameters. The pixel-based correction for serial CTE currently runs only on full-frame WFC images obtained after SM4 (May 2009). Shortly following the publication of this report, science data corrected for both parallel and serial CTE will be available in the MAST archive.

AI.tldr: The study examines serial CTE in ACS/WFC, quantifies its effects on stellar photometry and centroids, and introduces a correction algorithm.
AI.motivation: To improve data accuracy by addressing serial CTE degradation similarly to parallel CTE, which was previously studied.
AI.method: Analyzed serial CTE trails in dark frames from hot pixels, compared them to parallel trails, and modified CALACS to correct serial CTE losses.
AI.result: Serial CTE causes 0.005-0.02 mag photometric losses and 0.01-0.035 pixel centroid shifts. Corrections now exist for post-SM4 full-frame images.
AI.conclusion: Implementing serial CTE corrections alongside parallel ones enhances WFC data quality, with corrected data soon available in MAST.

title: Formation and Evolution of Antimatter Objects
summary: The fundamental question of baryogenesis and the problem of matter-antimatter asymmetry motivate this study into the formation and evolution of antimatter objects in the early Universe. Hypothesize is the existence of isolated antimatter domains in a baryon-asymmetric Universe that survive until the era of first star formation ($Z \approx 20$). By assuming CPT-symmetry, the thermodynamics, mechanics, and energy dynamics of an antimatter gas cloud (composed of antihydrogen and antihelium) are treated symmetrically to their primordial matter counterparts. Analysis demonstrates the physical feasibility of the gravitational collapse process for a conservatively estimated antimatter domain ($\approx 5 \times 10^3 M_{\odot}$). The initial conditions easily satisfy the Jeans and Bonnor-Ebert mass criteria, indicating a high propensity for instability and runaway collapse. The subsequent dynamical evolution, driven by $\bar{H}_2$ cooling, is predicted to proceed identically to that of Population III star formation, leading to the formation of a dense, adiabatic anti-protostellar core. The theoretical viability of a true antistar hinges upon a critical assumption: the physical possibility of antinuclear fusion (e.g., the antiproton cycle) under extreme core conditions. Assuming this symmetry holds, the collapse is predicted to yield massive antistars ($\gtrsim 22 M_{\odot}$). This suggests that if antimatter domains formed in the early Universe, they likely underwent stellar formation. Observational constraints on the existence of these objects must rely on the detection of characteristic high-energy $γ$-ray or X-ray signals resulting from matter-antimatter annihilation at the domain boundaries or during mass accretion.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the feasibility of antimatter domains surviving in the early universe and forming antistars through gravitational collapse, assuming symmetric thermodynamics with matter and viable antinuclear fusion.
AI.motivation: The study addresses baryogenesis and the matter-antimatter asymmetry problem by investigating if isolated antimatter domains could have formed antistars, providing insights into early universe dynamics.
AI.method: Using CPT symmetry, the paper models the thermodynamics and dynamics of an antimatter gas cloud (antihydrogen/antihelium), applying Jeans/Bonnor-Ebert criteria and simulating collapse via antihydrogen cooling analogous to Population III star formation.
AI.result: The antimatter domain (~5,000 solar masses) meets collapse criteria, leading to a dense anti-core. Assuming antinuclear fusion, massive antistars (~22+ solar masses) could form, similar to normal stars.
AI.conclusion: Antimatter domains could form antistars if antinuclear fusion is possible. Detection requires observing gamma/X-rays from annihilation at domain boundaries or during accretion, offering a testable prediction for cosmology.

title: The emergent Big Bang scenario
summary: This letter proposes a new avenue for understanding the cosmological singularity. The standard cosmological model contains a generic initial singularity usually referred to as the {\em big bang}. Herein, we present a novel idea to extend the description of our Universe beyond this limit. The proposal relies on rewriting physics in a purely Riemannian, {\em i.e.} locally Euclidean, 4-dimensional space and the emergence of Lorentzian patches owing to the interaction of all matter fields to a clock field that is responsible for a signature change. If our universe is contained within one of these patches, the initial singularity is replaced by a smooth boundary on which the signature of the physical metric flips. In this letter, we first define the model and draw the necessary conditions on its arbitrary functions for solutions to exist. Next, we prove the existence of solutions that lead to an emergent universe with a primordial (almost) de Sitter phase. To finish, we discuss the consequences of this construction for the universe on scales much larger than our observable universe: a large ``Euclidean sea'' in which Lorentzian islands locally emerge and host an expanding universe potentially similar to ours. While speculative, this scenario has specific features that can be tested, and the present letter sets the basis for further phenomenological investigations.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a novel approach to resolve the cosmological singularity by describing the universe in a Riemannian (Euclidean) framework where Lorentzian regions emerge due to a clock field interaction, replacing the big bang with a smooth metric signature flip.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of the standard cosmological model, which includes a generic initial singularity, by offering a new framework that extends beyond this singularity and provides a smooth cosmological description.
AI.method: The authors redefine physics in a 4D Riemannian space with a clock field inducing metric signature changes. They derive conditions for solutions, prove the existence of emergent de Sitter phases, and explore large-scale implications of a Euclidean 'sea' with Lorentzian islands.
AI.result: Solutions exist that generate an emergent universe with an early de Sitter phase, replacing the big bang singularity. A large-scale 'Euclidean sea' concept is introduced where multiple Lorentzian universes could emerge.
AI.conclusion: The model provides a testable framework to resolve the cosmological singularity and suggests a multiverse-like structure where our observable universe is part of a larger Euclidean background, opening avenues for further phenomenological research.

title: Axion-Like Electrophilic Portal for Pion Dark Matter
summary: We investigate a scenario where Strongly Interacting Massive Particle (SIMP) dark matter interacts with an axion-like particle (ALP) that couples exclusively to electrons. This minimal setup provides interactions which enforce thermal equilibrium between dark matter and the SM in the early Universe. We analyze the cosmological evolution of the dark sector and the constraints arising from dark matter annihilations, ALP laboratory searches and astrophysical observations. Our results show that the allowed parameter space is wider than previous studies and an ALP with mass $m_a \sim {\cal O}(10)~\text{MeV}$ can act as a viable portal between the visible and dark sectors. Interestingly, this mass range overlaps with the parameter space suggested by the reported $X_{17}$ anomaly. Furthermore, the introduction of non-vanishing $θ$ angle in the dark sector of the model opens up the parameter space to heavy ALP masses.

AI.tldr: The paper explores a SIMP dark matter model interacting with an axion-like particle (ALP) coupled to electrons, finding a viable DM-ALP portal with m_a ~10 MeV, overlapping with the X17 anomaly and allowing heavier ALPs with a non-zero θ angle.
AI.motivation: To study thermal equilibrium mechanisms between dark matter and the Standard Model via ALP interactions and expand the allowed parameter space for dark matter models.
AI.method: Analyzing cosmological evolution of the dark sector, considering constraints from dark matter annihilations, ALP lab searches, and astrophysical data.
AI.result: Found wider parameter space than prior studies; ALP mass ~10 MeV viable as portal, overlapping with X17 anomaly; non-zero θ angle allows heavier ALP masses.
AI.conclusion: The proposed model effectively bridges dark matter and visible sectors via ALPs, offering a testable framework compatible with experimental anomalies and expanding valid ALP mass ranges.

title: SQUIDPOL: Seoul National University QUadruple Imaging Device for POLarimetry
comment: 15 pages, 12 figures. Submitted to JKAS on February 3, 2026
summary: We present SQUIDPOL, a low-cost, multi-channel optical imaging polarimeter that performs simultaneous linear polarization measurements using a rotating half-wave plate, a non-polarizing beam splitter, and four wire-grid filters. We show that the off-the-shelf non-polarizing beam splitter introduces measurable polarization-dependent systematics, which can bias polarimetric measurements if left uncorrected. We quantify this effect for both transmitted and reflected beams and incorporate a correction scheme into the data-analysis pipeline. On-sky validation demonstrates stable and reproducible performance, achieving a polarization accuracy of about 0.15 percent for bright polarized standard stars. Mounted on the 60-cm Ritchey-Chretien telescope (focal length 4200 mm, f/7) at the Pyeongchang Observatory of Seoul National University, SQUIDPOL provides an effective common field of view of 13.5 by 8.2 arcminutes with a pixel scale of 0.45 arcseconds per pixel and supports standard B, V, R_C, and I_C filters.

AI.tldr: SQUIDPOL is a cost-effective multi-channel optical polarimeter using a rotating half-wave plate and four wire-grid filters. It addresses polarization-dependent systematic errors from a non-polarizing beam splitter, correcting for biases and achieving 0.15% accuracy on polarized standard stars.
AI.motivation: To develop an affordable polarimeter that corrects systematic errors caused by off-the-shelf components, enabling reliable polarization measurements.
AI.method: Employs a rotating half-wave plate, non-polarizing beam splitter, and four wire-grid filters. Quantifies polarization-dependent systematics in both transmitted and reflected beams, integrating a correction scheme into data analysis.
AI.result: Demonstrates stable on-sky performance with 0.15% polarization accuracy for bright standard stars. Achieves a 13.5x8.2 arcminute field of view and 0.45 arcsec/pixel resolution on a 60cm telescope.
AI.conclusion: SQUIDPOL successfully combines low cost with high accuracy, validated through observational testing, making it a valuable tool for polarimetric studies in astronomy.

title: Gravitational-Wave Signals for Supernova Explosions of Three-Dimensional Progenitors
comment: 37 pages, 23 figures, 1 table; submitted to PRD
summary: Core-collapse supernovae (SNe) are sources of gravitational waves (GWs) produced by hydrodynamical instabilities and highly time-dependent anisotropies of the neutrino radiation. In this work we analyze both contributions to the GW signal for two state-of-the-art three-dimensional (3D) SN models computed with the Prometheus-Vertex neutrino-hydrodynamics code. In contrast to the far majority of models analyzed for GWs so far, our core-collapse simulations were started with 12.28 M_sun (18.88 M_sun) progenitors, whose final hour (7 min) of convective oxygen-shell burning was computed in 3D and featured a vigorous oxygen-neon shell merger. The corresponding large-scale asymmetries in the oxygen layer are conducive to buoyancy-aided neutrino-driven explosions. The models were continuously evolved in 3D from the pre-collapse evolution until 5.11 s (1.68 s) after the core bounce. The GW signals result from the well-known dynamical phenomena in the SN core such as prompt postshock convection, neutrino-driven convection, the standing accretion shock instability, proto-neutron star oscillations, and anisotropic ejecta expansion. They do not exhibit any new or specific features that can be unambiguously connected to the powerful pre-collapse activity in the progenitors, but we identify interesting differences compared to results in the literature. We also discuss measurement prospects by interferometers, confirming that GW signals from future Galactic SNe will be detectable with existing and next-generation experiments working in the frequency range f ~ 1-2000 Hz.

AI.tldr: The study examines gravitational wave signals from core-collapse supernovae using detailed 3D simulations starting from pre-collapse stages. Despite vigorous oxygen-neon shell mergers and large asymmetries, the resulting GW signals don't show unique features linked to pre-collapse activity but differ from previous findings, offering new insights for detection with existing and future interferometers.
AI.motivation: To analyze gravitational wave contributions from hydrodynamical instabilities and neutrino radiation anisotropies in 3D core-collapse simulations that include the final stages of progenitor evolution, unlike most prior studies.
AI.method: Used Prometheus-Vertex code for 3D neutrino-hydrodynamics simulations of 12.28 and 18.88 solar mass progenitors, tracking from pre-collapse oxygen-shell burning through 5 seconds post-bounce. Evaluated GW signals from core dynamics including convective processes, shock instabilities, proto-neutron star oscillations, and ejecta anisotropy.
AI.result: GW signals originated from standard post-bounce phenomena but lacked distinctive features tied to pre-collapse oxygen-neon merger activity. Differences from previous models were noted, with detectability confirmed for future Galactic supernovae by interferometers in 1-2000 Hz range.
AI.conclusion: While pre-collapse asymmetries didn't produce unique GW signatures, the models highlight variability among SN GW signals requiring detailed 3D simulations. Detectability remains promising for upcoming experiments, emphasizing the need for continuous multi-messenger observations.

title: Dynamical hair growth in black hole binaries in Einstein-scalar-Gauss-Bonnet gravity
summary: Within the framework of scalar-tensor theories of gravity, certain models can evade classical black hole no-hair theorems. A well-known example is Einstein-scalar-Gauss-Bonnet gravity, where black holes carrying a scalar charge can exist. We find that, within this theory, binary black holes initially described by General Relativity can acquire scalar charges once they reach a critical orbital separation ("dynamical scalarization"). We develop a simple semi-analytic model, based on the adiabatic conservation of the total Wald entropy, to estimate the scalar charge evolution during the binary inspiral. We also run fully nonlinear numerical-relativity simulations for different configurations, finding consistent results. The gravitational-wave phase difference between Einstein-scalar-Gauss-Bonnet and General Relativity waveforms, which we use to assess detectability, is also computed. We find that dynamical scalarization might be observable in nearly equal-mass binary black hole mergers with third-generation ground-based gravitational-wave detectors, in a narrow range of the dimensional coupling of the theory.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates dynamical scalarization in Einstein-scalar-Gauss-Bonnet gravity, showing that binary black holes in general relativity can acquire scalar charges at critical orbital separations. Using semi-analytic models and numerical simulations, they predict detectability in third-generation gravitational-wave detectors for specific coupling parameters.
AI.motivation: To explore how scalar-tensor theories evade black hole no-hair theorems and test the observability of modified gravity effects in binary black hole systems through gravitational waves.
AI.method: Developed a semi-analytic model using adiabatic Wald entropy conservation and performed numerical-relativity simulations to study scalar charge evolution during binary inspiral. Calculated gravitational-wave phase differences for detectability analysis.
AI.result: Demonstrated that dynamical scalarization occurs in binaries, leading to observable phase differences in gravitational waves detectable by future detectors under certain coupling constants.
AI.conclusion: Dynamical scalarization provides a testable prediction for modified gravity theories, potentially observable in equal-mass black hole mergers with next-gen detectors, offering a new avenue to constrain scalar-tensor theories.

title: Exploring Thermalization and Multi-Freeze-Out Effects in Pb-Pb collisions Based on Tsallis pT Distributions
summary:
This study investigates transverse-momentum (pT) distributions of pi-, pi+, K-, K+, p, pbar, K0s, and Lambda in several centrality classes of Pb-Pb collisions at sqrt(sNN) = 2.76 TeV. The measured spectra are analyzed with the Tsallis non-extensive distribution, from which the effective temperature T, non-extensive parameter q, and the mean transverse momentum mean_pT are extracted for each particle species and centrality interval. To disentangle thermal and collective effects, the mean kinetic freeze-out temperature T0 is obtained from the intercept of the T-versus-mass relation, while the average transverse flow velocity betaT is extracted from the slope of mean_pT versus the mean moving mass for pions, kaons, and protons.
  The results show that T increases and q decreases with increasing centrality, indicating a hotter and more equilibrated system in central collisions. A clear mass dependence of T supports a multi-freeze-out scenario, with heavier particles decoupling earlier. Both T0 and betaT rise from peripheral to mid-central collisions before saturating toward central events, which may suggest the onset of collective behavior or changes in freeze-out dynamics. These observations provide new insights into the thermal and dynamical properties of the medium created in heavy-ion collisions at the LHC.

AI.tldr: This study analyzes transverse momentum distributions of various particles in Pb-Pb collisions at 2.76 TeV using the Tsallis distribution, revealing thermal and collective effects linked to collision centrality.
AI.motivation: To investigate the thermal and dynamical properties of the quark-gluon plasma by disentangling freeze-out conditions and collective flow effects in heavy-ion collisions.
AI.method: Measured pT spectra for pi±, K±, p/pbar, K0s, Lambda particles are analyzed with Tsallis non-extensive distributions to extract parameters T, q, mean_pT. Thermal parameters T0 and transverse flow velocity betaT extracted via mass-dependent fits.
AI.result: Effective temperature T increases with centrality while non-extensive parameter q decreases, indicating greater system equilibration centrally. T shows mass dependence supporting multi-freeze-out scenarios. T0 and betaT rise then saturate, suggesting collective behavior onset.
AI.conclusion: The results indicate a hotter, more equilibrated system in central collisions with evolving collectivity. The findings shed light on medium dynamics and freeze-out mechanisms in LHC Pb-Pb collisions.

title: Unlocking the dynamics of Young Stellar Objects: Time-Domain Interferometry with six 4-m class telescopes
comment: 3 pages, 2 figures, White paper presented for Expanding Horizons Transforming Astronomy in the 2040s
summary: The dynamics of the inner regions of young stellar objects (YSOs) is driven by a variety of physical phenomena, from magnetospheres and accretion to the dust sublimation rim and inner disk flows. These inner environments evolve on timescales of hours to days, exactly when bursts, dips, and rapid structural changes carry the most valuable information about star and planet formations, but remain hardly reachable with current facilities. A better reactive infrastructure with six or more telescopes, combined with alerts from large time-domain surveys (e.g., at the era of LSST/Rubin type facilities), and equipped with instruments spanning from the V-band to the thermal infrared (N), would provide the instantaneous uv-coverage and spectral diagnostics needed to unambiguously interpret and image these events as they happen. Such a world's first time-domain interferometric observatory would enable qualitatively new science: directly linking optical and infrared variability to spatially resolved changes in magnetospheric accretion, inner-disk geometry, and dust and gas dynamics in the innermost astronomical unit. Crucially, connecting these processes to outer-scale unresolved information from JWST, ALMA, and the ELT would yield a complete tomography of the planet-forming region.

AI.tldr: The paper argues for the development of a new time-domain interferometric observatory with multiple telescopes and instruments to study the dynamic inner regions of young stellar objects (YSOs), aiming to capture rapid events like bursts and structural changes, and link these observations with existing telescopes like JWST and ALMA for comprehensive analysis of star and planet formation.
AI.motivation: Current facilities are insufficient to monitor the fast-evolving inner regions of YSOs (timescales of hours to days), missing critical data on accretion, magnetospheres, and inner disk dynamics crucial for understanding star and planet formation.
AI.method: Proposing a reactive interferometric network with six or more telescopes equipped with instruments across V-band to thermal infrared, triggered by alerts from surveys (e.g., LSST/Rubin), to provide real-time uv-coverage and spectral diagnostics of transient events.
AI.result: Such a system would allow spatially resolved observations of magnetospheric accretion, inner-disk geometry, and dust/gas dynamics in YSOs' innermost regions, combined with data from JWST/ALMA/ELT for full tomography of planet-forming regions.
AI.conclusion: A dedicated time-domain interferometric observatory is essential to achieve real-time monitoring and comprehensive modeling of YSO inner regions, revolutionizing studies of early stellar and planetary system evolution.

title: Radiation-hydrodynamics of star-disc collisions for quasi-periodic eruptions
comment: Submitted to A&A, comments are welcome!
summary: Quasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs) are recently discovered transients of unknown nature occurring near supermassive black holes, which feature bright X-ray bursts separated by hours to days. A promising model for QPEs is the star-disc collisions model, where a star repeatedly interacts with an accretion disc around a black hole, creating shocks that expel dense outflows of gas from which radiation emerges. We investigate the dynamics of the star-disc collisions, the properties of the outflows, and the resulting radiation signatures. Our study focuses on the generic case where the star remains unperturbed by the collision and the stellar crossing time through the disc is sufficiently long for shocked gas to flow around the star. We performed a three-dimensional (3D) radiation-hydrodynamics simulation of the star-disc collision. The star was modeled as a solid, spherical body, and the interaction was simulated for a small, local section of the accretion disc. We found that star-disc collisions generate a nearly paraboloidal bow shock. The heating of gas is not confined to the column of gas directly ahead of the star but also extends laterally as the shock front expands sideways while traveling with the star. As the star crosses the disc, it injects momentum preferentially along its direction of motion, leading to an asymmetric redistribution of energy and momentum. As a result, two outflows emerge on opposite sides of the disc with different properties: the forward outflow expands faster, contains more mass, carries more energy, and is about twice as luminous as the backward outflow. Our findings suggest that the asymmetry in outflow properties and luminosity arises naturally from the collision dynamics, offering a possible explanation for the alternating strong-weak flare patterns observed in several QPE sources.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how star-disc collisions near supermassive black holes can generate quasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs), using 3D simulations to show asymmetric outflows and radiation signatures that match observed flare patterns.
AI.motivation: To understand the mechanism behind QPEs, which are mysterious X-ray burst events near black holes, by testing the star-disc collision model.
AI.method: Performed 3D radiation-hydrodynamics simulations of a star passing through an accretion disc, modeling the star as a solid sphere and focusing on a local disc region.
AI.result: Simulations revealed paraboloidal bow shocks, asymmetric forward/backward outflows (forward outflow being more massive, luminous, and energetic), and lateral heating effects, explaining alternating flare strengths.
AI.conclusion: Star-disc collisions naturally produce asymmetric luminous outflows, supporting them as a candidate mechanism for QPEs' repeating burst patterns.

title: The favoured twin: on the dynamical response of twin stars to perturbations
summary: If a strong first-order phase transition takes place at sufficiently high rest-mass densities in the equation of state (EOS) modelling compact stars, a new branch will appear in the mass-radius sequence of stable equilibria. This branch will be populated by stars comprising a quark-matter core and a hadronic-matter envelope, i.e., hybrid stars, which represent ``twin-star'' solutions to equilibria having the same mass but a fully hadronic EOS. While both branches are stable to linear perturbations, it is unclear which of the twin solutions is the ``favoured'' one, that is, which of the two configurations is expected to be found in nature. We assess this point by performing a large campaign of general-relativistic simulations aimed at assessing the response of compact stars on the two branches to perturbations of various strength. In this way, we find that, independently of whether the stars populate the hadronic or the twin branch, their response is characterised by a critical-perturbation strength such that the star will oscillate on the original branch for subcritical perturbations and migrate to the neighbouring branch for supercritical perturbations while conserving rest-mass. Because the critical values are different for stars with the same rest-mass but sitting on either branch, it is possible to define as favoured the part of the branch that has the largest critical perturbation, thus correcting the common wisdom that stellar models on the twin branch are the favoured ones. Interestingly, we show that the binding energies on the two branches can be used to deduce without simulations which of the stellar configurations is more likely to be found in nature.

AI.tldr: The paper demonstrates that the stability of hybrid stars (twin stars) depends on the critical perturbation strength, challenging the assumption that twin branches are inherently favored. Binding energies determine the favored configuration without simulations.
AI.motivation: To determine which branch (hadronic or twin) of compact stars is naturally favored when a first-order phase transition occurs, addressing uncertainty in previous assumptions about stability.
AI.method: General-relativistic simulations analyzing the response of stars on both branches to varying perturbations, comparing critical perturbation strengths and binding energies.
AI.result: The branch with higher critical perturbation strength is favored. Binding energy differences alone can predict favored configurations without simulations.
AI.conclusion: The common belief that twin stars are naturally favored is refined: the favored branch is determined by critical perturbation thresholds and binding energy analysis, not just phase transitions.

title: Generalized Neutrino Interactions: constraints and parametrizations
summary: Generalized neutrino interactions (GNI) are emerging as a convenient framework for describing effective scalar, vector, and tensor interactions. Such interactions arise naturally from extensions of the Standard Model that aim to explain neutrino properties and their mass origin. In this paper, we carefully study the two more common parametrizations for GNI and how to relate them. This allows us to compare bounds obtained from CEvNS and deep-inelastic scattering under the same footing. In addition, we present the current bounds from CEvNS measurements by COHERENT and compare them to those obtained from deep inelastic scattering on the same level. Our results focus on neutrino-quark interactions, and illustrate the complementarity between experiments working at different scales for GNI, showing that scalar interactions are better constrained by low-energy experiments like COHERENT, while tensor interactions are robustly constrained from deep inelastic scattering.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes two common parametrizations of Generalized Neutrino Interactions (GNI) to compare constraints from Coherent Elastic Neutrino-Nucleus Scattering (CEvNS) and deep-inelastic scattering experiments, showing scalar interactions are better constrained at low energy while tensor interactions require high-energy data.
AI.motivation: To unify and compare bounds on GNI from different experimental approaches (CEvNS and deep-inelastic scattering) under consistent frameworks.
AI.method: Relating two GNI parametrization schemes, analyzing current CEvNS bounds from COHERENT, and comparing them to deep inelastic scattering constraints.
AI.result: Scalar interactions are more tightly constrained by low-energy COHERENT experiments, whereas tensor interactions are better bounded by high-energy deep inelastic scattering experiments, highlighting the complementarity of multi-scale experimental approaches.
AI.conclusion: Combining data from low-energy and high-energy experiments is essential for comprehensive GNI constraint, as each scale targets different interaction types effectively.

title: Euclid. Properties and performance of the NISP signal estimator
summary: The Euclid spacecraft, located at the second Lagrangian point of the Sun-Earth system, hosts the Near-Infrared Spectrometer and Photometer (NISP) instrument. NISP is equipped with a mosaic of 16 HgCdTe-based detectors to acquire near-infrared photometric and spectroscopic data. To meet the spacecraft's constraints on computational resources and telemetry bandwidth, the near-infrared signal is processed onboard via a dedicated hardware-software architecture designed to fulfil the stringent Euclid's data-quality requirements. A custom application software, running on the two NISP data processing units, implements the NISP signal estimator: an ad-hoc algorithm which delivers accurate flux measurements and simultaneously estimates the quality of signal estimation through the quality factor parameter. This paper investigates the properties of the NISP signal estimator by evaluating its performance during the early flight operations of the NISP instrument. First, we revisit the assumptions on which the inference of the near-infrared signal is based and investigate the origin of the main systematics of the signal estimator through Monte Carlo simulations. Then, we test the flight performance of the NISP signal estimator. Results indicate a systematic bias lower than 0.01 e/s for 99% of the NISP pixel array, well within the noise budget of the estimated signal. We also derive an analytical expression for the variance of the NISP signal estimator, demonstrating its validity, particularly when the covariance matrix is not pre-computed. Finally, we provide a robust statistical framework to interpret the QF parameter, analyse its dependence on the signal estimator bias, and show its sensitivity to cosmic ray hits on NISP detectors. Our findings corroborate previous results on the NISP signal estimator and suggest a leading-order correction based on the agreement between flight data and simulations.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates the performance of the NISP signal estimator onboard the Euclid spacecraft during early flight operations, demonstrating its accuracy and providing a statistical framework for interpreting the quality factor parameter.
AI.motivation: To verify the NISP signal estimator's compliance with Euclid's data-quality requirements, assess systematics, and validate its statistical properties under real flight conditions.
AI.method: Monte Carlo simulations were used to investigate systematic biases. Flight data were analyzed to test estimator performance, derive variance expressions, and establish a framework for interpreting the quality factor (QF) parameter.
AI.result: The estimator shows a systematic bias <0.01 e/s for 99% of pixels, meeting noise budgets. An analytical variance formula was validated, and QF's sensitivity to cosmic rays and bias was quantified.
AI.conclusion: The NISP signal estimator meets mission specifications, enabling reliable data processing. Recommendations include applying a leading-order correction based on flight-simulation agreement.

title: Lightcurve Modelling of 2,205 ZTF DR2 Type~Ia Supernovae: Implications for SN Ia Physics and Cosmology
summary: We fit the multi-band light curves of 2,205 Type Ia supernovae (SNe~Ia) from the Zwicky Transient Facility DR2 with a one-zone radioactive decay model with a phenomenological addition to include Fe recombination physics. We find a strong correlation between inferred nickel mass and SALT2 stretch, which within our simplified modelling is linked to larger ejecta masses providing longer diffusion times, providing a physical basis for the brighter-slower relation. SN~Ia in low-mass hosts ($\log_{10}(M_*/M_\odot) < 10$) produce $12\%$ more $^{56}$Ni than those in high-mass hosts ($ΔM_{\rm Ni} = 0.13~M_\odot$), linking the host-galaxy mass step to ejecta properties and hinting at metallicity or age-dependent burning efficiencies. This suggests that standardisation based on physical parameters may remove the mass-step. SN~1991T-like events show higher ejecta masses (median $1.64~M_\odot$ vs. $1.38~M_\odot$ for normals) and produce $30\%$ more $^{56}$Ni, with $84\%$ having super-Chandrasekhar masses. Through Hierarchical modelling of $902$ SNe ($z \leq 0.06$), we find thermonuclear supernovae can be well described by a Gaussian distribution in ejecta mass and nickel mass with $μ_{\rm ej} = 1.26 \pm 0.01~M_\odot$ ($σ_{\rm ej} = 0.33 \pm 0.01~M_\odot$) and $μ_{\rm Ni} = 0.64 \pm 0.06~M_\odot$ ($σ_{\rm Ni} = 0.42 \pm 0.02~M_\odot$), respectively. This leads to inferred fractions of $43 \pm 2\%$ sub-$M_{\rm Ch}$ ($<1.2~M_\odot$), $34 \pm 1\%$ near-$M_{\rm Ch}$ ($1.2$--$1.5~M_\odot$), and $24 \pm 2\%$ super-$M_{\rm Ch}$ ($>1.5~M_\odot$) events. This work provides a step towards holistic physical characterization of the local SN~Ia population, reinforcing the physical basis of SN~Ia standardization while quantifying diversity and environmental dependencies critical for understanding progenitor physics and mitigating systematics in precision cosmology.

AI.tldr: This study analyzes light curves of 2,205 Type Ia supernovae using a radioactive decay model with Fe recombination, revealing correlations between nickel mass, host galaxy mass, and ejecta properties. It finds that supernovae in low-mass galaxies produce more nickel, and SN 1991T-like events have higher ejecta and nickel masses, including super-Chandrasekhar masses. The analysis supports physical standardization for cosmology by quantifying diversity and environmental effects.
AI.motivation: To understand the physical basis of the brighter-slower relation in Type Ia supernovae and quantify environmental dependencies (host galaxy mass) on their ejecta properties, which is crucial for improving standardization in cosmological studies and reducing systematic uncertainties.
AI.method: Fit multi-band light curves of 2,205 SNe Ia from Zwicky Transient Facility DR2 using a one-zone radioactive decay model with a phenomenological addition for Fe recombination. Hierarchical modeling of 902 nearby SNe to derive Gaussian distributions of ejecta and nickel masses. Compare properties between different subclasses (e.g., SN 1991T-like vs normal) and host galaxy mass environments.
AI.result: Strong correlation between nickel mass and SALT2 stretch; low-mass host SNe have ~12% more Ni; SN 1991T-like events show 30% higher Ni and super-Chandrasekhar masses. Ejecta masses distributed as (1.26±0.01) M☉ with 3 categories (<1.2M☉, 1.2-1.5M☉, >1.5M☉) at 43%, 34%, 24% fractions respectively.
AI.conclusion: Physical parameters (ejecta/nickel mass) can standardize SNe Ia beyond empirical methods. Host galaxy mass steps correlate with ejecta properties, suggesting metallicity/burning efficiency links. Diversity in masses and nickel production highlights the need for environmental corrections in cosmology. This work advances physical understanding for improving precision in cosmological distance measurements.

title: Comment on ''The space-time line element for static ellipsoidal objects''
summary: A recent paper proposes a static ellipsoidal space-time metric that reduces to Schwarzschild. After examining the corrected line element using Maple's Differential geometry package, we find that the Einstein tendor and Ricci scalar are non-zero, and the metric yields non-zero pressures when interpreted as an anisotropic fluid. Thus, it does not represent a vacuum solution. We also checked a cited ellipsoidal metric from the literature and found it likewise fails to satisfy the vacuum Einstein equations.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes a proposed static ellipsoidal space-time metric, finding it does not represent a valid vacuum solution as it produces non-zero Einstein tensor, Ricci scalar, and non-zero pressures indicative of an anisotropic fluid.
AI.motivation: To verify whether the proposed ellipsoidal metric is a valid vacuum solution (requiring zero Einstein tensor) as it claims to reduce to Schwarzschild.
AI.method: Used Maple's Differential Geometry package to compute Einstein tensor and Ricci scalar for the metric. Also checked a cited ellipsoidal metric from literature for vacuum conditions.
AI.result: Both the new and cited metrics yield non-zero Einstein tensors and Ricci scalars. The new metric表现出 non-zero pressures when interpreted as anisotropic fluid, violating vacuum requirements.
AI.conclusion: The examined ellipsoidal metrics are invalid as vacuum solutions since they don't satisfy Einstein's equations for empty spacetime.

title: Hydrogenated carbon structures as directional sub-GeV dark matter detectors
summary: We propose hydrogenated carbon structures as targets with a remarkable sensitivity to dark matter-nucleon interactions, in the mass range between the 1 MeV and 100 MeV. The ejection of a proton following the interaction with a dark matter particle is a quasi-elastic process, with an extremely small energy threshold, and a clear experimental signature. The proposed detectors are simple, technologically ready, and inexpensive. Yet, they can be considerably more sensitive than current experiments. They also allow strong directionality, to be used towards efficient background rejection.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes hydrogenated carbon targets for dark matter detection, offering high sensitivity, low energy thresholds, clear signatures, and directional capabilities. These detectors are simple, cost-effective, and surpass current technology in sensitivity.
AI.motivation: Dark matter detection requires sensitive, efficient methods. Existing detectors have limitations in energy thresholds and background rejection. Hydrogenated carbon structures address these issues with their inherent properties.
AI.method: Using hydrogenated carbon targets that can detect dark matter interactions via proton ejection, a quasi-elastic process with low energy thresholds. Detectors leverage the clear experimental signature of proton ejection and directionality for background suppression.
AI.result: The proposed detectors are simpler, cheaper, and more sensitive than current experiments, with potential to explore uncharted dark matter mass ranges (1-100 MeV) effectively.
AI.conclusion: Hydrogenated carbon-based detectors represent a promising advancement in dark matter research, enabling more precise measurements and efficient background handling due to their directionality and sensitivity.

title: A Method for Thermal Radiation Transport Using Backward Characteristic Tracing
comment: Submitted to Journal of Computational Physics
summary: Thermal radiation transport is a challenging problem in computational physics that has long been approached primarily in one of a few standard ways: approximate moment methods (for instance P$_1$ or M$_1$), implicit Monte Carlo, discrete ordinates, and long characteristics. In this work we consider the efficacy of the Method of (Long) Characteristics (MOC) applied to thermal radiation transport. Along the way we develop three major ideas: transporting MOC particles backwards in time from quadrature grids at the end of the timestep, limiting the computational cost of these backward characteristics by terminating transport once optical depths along rays become sufficiently large, and timestep-dependent closures with multigroup MOC solutions for a gray low-order system. We apply this method to a suite of standard radiation transport and radiation hydrodynamics test problems. We compare the method to several standard analytic and semi-analytic solutions, as well as implicit Monte Carlo, P$_1$, and discrete ordinates (S$_n$). We see that the method: gives excellent agreement with known results, has stability for large time steps, has the diffusion limit for large spatial cells, and achieves $\sim$20-70\% performance improvement when terminating optical depths at O(10-100) in the grey Marshak and crooked pipe problems. However, for the Coax radiation-hydrodynamics problem, we see that MOC is approximately two to three times slower than IMC-DDMC and S$_n$ in its current implementation.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates the Method of (Long) Characteristics (MOC) for thermal radiation transport, proposing backward time transport, early optical depth termination, and timestep-dependent closures to improve efficiency. It shows competitiveness in some test cases but remains slower than IMC-DDMC and Sₙ in radiation-hydrodynamics problems.
AI.motivation: Address the computational challenges of thermal radiation transport, exploring MOC's potential to offer stability and performance improvements over traditional methods like P₁, Sₙ, and implicit Monte Carlo. Aim to reduce computational costs while maintaining accuracy.
AI.method: Developed three key innovations: backward time-transport of MOC particles from quadrature grids, early termination of characteristics when optical depths reach O(10-100), and dynamic timestep closures for multigroup MOC solutions. Applied to standard test problems, compared against analytical/semi-analytical solutions, IMC, P₁, and Sₙ.
AI.result: Achieved excellent agreement with known results, stability for large time steps, diffusion limit validity. Performance gains of 20-70% in Marshak and crooked pipe problems; however, MOC was 2-3× slower than IMC-DDMC and Sₙ in Coax radiation-hydrodynamics.
AI.conclusion: MOC shows promise with efficiency improvements in certain scenarios but requires further optimization for complex radiation-hydrodynamics cases where current implementation lags behind alternatives. Highlights trade-offs between accuracy and computational cost.

title: An infrared echo from a circumstellar disk in the hydrogen- and helium-poor SN 2024aecx
summary: We present near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy of the hydrogen- and helium-poor (Type Ic) supernova (SN) 2024aecx that displays a strong NIR excess emerging 32 days post peak. SN 2024aecx is a peculiar SN Ic that exhibited luminous shock-cooling emission at early times, suggestive of close-in circumstellar medium (CSM), unexpected for this class of SNe. Its early NIR spectra are typical for a SN Ic but with strong CI absorption features. By ~32 days post peak, the spectra show a strong NIR excess, while maintaining normal optical colors, unprecedented for SNe Ic. We find that the NIR excess is well fit with a single-temperature, optically thin dust model with declining temperature, increasing mass, and roughly constant luminosity over time. The NIR excess appears too promptly for dust to have formed in the SN ejecta, indicating an IR echo from pre-existing dust in the CSM. The IR echo is likely powered by the relatively slowly evolving SN peak light, and not the brief shock cooling emission, as the latter requires unrealistically high CSM densities to explain the observed dust mass. We consider different potential CSM geometries and find that a thick face-on disk with an inner edge around $5\times 10^{16}$ cm can best explain the dust mass and temperature evolution. In this scenario, the SN shock should start interacting with this CSM $440\pm200$ days post explosion. CSM around SN Ic is rare, and follow-up observations of SN 2024aecx will probe the mass-loss process responsible for removing hydrogen and helium from their progenitor star.

AI.tldr: SN 2024aecx is a unique Type Ic supernova showing an anomalous near-infrared excess due to an IR echo from pre-existing dust in a circumstellar medium (CSM) disk. This indicates a rare CSM geometry suggesting progenitor mass loss.
AI.motivation: To understand the origin of NIR excess and CSM interaction in Type Ic SNe, which typically lack detectable CSM.
AI.method: Analyzed NIR spectroscopy data and modeled dust properties/CSM geometry using optically thin dust and geometric constraints.
AI.result: Confirmed IR echo from pre-existing dust in a thick face-on disk; predicts CSM interaction begins ~440 days post-explosion.
AI.conclusion: SN Ic progenitors may undergo significant mass loss forming structured CSM, requiring follow-up to study mass-loss mechanisms.

title: An Improved Torsion Balance Test of the Equivalence Principle Towards the Sun
summary: We search for violations of the Equivalence Principle towards the Sun using a rotating torsion balance apparatus. We set 95\%-confidence limits on violations with beryllium and aluminum test bodies of $η_{\odot, Be-Al} \leq 2.1 \times 10^{-13}$. These results are a factor of four improvement of previously reported results towards the Sun and a $\sim20\%$ improvement on previous torsion balance tests regardless of source.

AI.tldr: The paper presents improved limits on violations of the Equivalence Principle using a rotating torsion balance with beryllium and aluminum test bodies, achieving η_{☉, Be-Al} ≤ 2.1e-13, surpassing prior solar-based results by fourfold and outperforming other torsion balance tests by ~20%.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to rigorously test the validity of the Equivalence Principle, a foundational concept in general relativity, by searching for unexplained deviations in gravitational interactions towards the Sun. This ensures the robustness of gravitational theories and identifies potential new physics.
AI.method: A rotating torsion balance apparatus was employed, utilizing beryllium and aluminum test bodies to measure any unexpected accelerations inconsistent with the Equivalence Principle. Precision measurements under controlled conditions allowed constraint estimation of parametrized violations.
AI.result: 95% confidence limits of η_{☉, Be-Al} ≤ 2.1x10^-13 were established, representing a 4x improvement over past solar-based experiments and a ~20% enhancement over previous torsion balance tests irrespective of source.
AI.conclusion: The results reinforce the Equivalence Principle's validity within current measurement limits, setting tighter constraints on potential violations. This advances gravitational physics by requiring more stringent theoretical models and guiding future experimental designs to probe even smaller scales.

title: Quantum Tomography of Fermion Pairs in $e^+e^-$ Collisions: Longitudinal Beam Polarization Effects
summary: We present a quantum tomography study of fermion pair production at future $e^+e^-$ colliders, emphasizing how longitudinal beam polarization controls the two-qubit spin density matrix. We study the processes $e^+ e^- \to t\bar{t},\ e^+e^-\to μ^+μ^-$ and Bhabha scattering $e^+e^-\to e^+e^-$, representing the mass threshold behavior, the $Z$ pole resonance and the $s/t$-channel interplay. We choose to focus on three key concepts: quantum entanglement via the concurrence $\mathcal{C}$, Bell nonlocality via the optimal Clauser Horne Shimony Holt (CHSH) parameter $\mathcal{B}$, and non-stabilizerness (``magic'') via the second stabilizer Rényi entropy $\mathcal{M}_2$. For the $s$-channel-dominated channels, longitudinal polarization mainly reshapes single-spin polarizations while leaving the spin-correlation matrix largely unchanged, rendering $\mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ comparatively robust, but inducing a pronounced variation of $\mathcal{M}_2$. In contrast, in Bhabha scattering, polarization modifies the relative contributions of the $s$-channel and $t$-channel and can strongly affect all three observables. The observability of entanglement, Bell nonlocality, and magic exceeds the $5σ$ level when both statistical and systematic uncertainties are included, establishing the fermion pair systems as ideal laboratories for quantum-information studies in high energy leptonic collisions. With optimized beam polarization, future $e^+e^-$ colliders will provide a unique opportunity to experimentally explore and influence quantum resources in particle interactions.

AI.tldr: This study uses quantum tomography to analyze fermion pair production in $e^+e^-$ collisions, focusing on how longitudinal beam polarization affects spin density matrices. Key observables include entanglement (concurrence), Bell nonlocality (CHSH parameter), and magic (Rényi entropy). Results show varying sensitivity to polarization across different processes, with Bhabha scattering showing strong effects on all three measures. Observables surpass 5σ significance, positioning future colliders as platforms for quantum information studies.
AI.motivation: To investigate how beam polarization controls spin-density correlations in fermion pair production, enabling precision measurements of quantum information properties (entanglement, nonlocality, magic) in high-energy physics experiments. This establishes their utility for quantum resource exploration in particle physics.
AI.method: Quantum tomography applied to three representative processes ($e^+e^-\to t\bar{t}$, $μ^+μ^-$, Bhabha scattering) at different energy regimes. Analytical calculations of spin-density matrices, concurrence $\mathcal{C}$, CHSH parameter $\mathcal{B}$, and magic $\mathcal{M}_2$ under varying longitudinal polarization conditions. Separation of $s$- vs $t$-channel contributions in Bhabha scattering.
AI.result: Longitudinal polarization primarily alters single-spin polarizations in $s$-channel processes, leaving correlations stable but strongly affecting magic. In Bhabha scattering, polarization modifies $s/t$ interference and impacts all three observables. All observables achieve >5σ observability with realistic uncertainties.
AI.conclusion: Future $e^+e^-$ colliders with optimized polarization can serve as precision labs for quantum information studies in particle interactions. Bhabha scattering emerges as particularly sensitive to polarization effects, offering unique opportunities to manipulate and study quantum resources in high-energy physics.

title: Star Grazing with Alumina Grass: Antireflection coatings in the visible and near-infrared on IPX-Clear Microlenses assisted by Grass-like Alumina
comment: 14 pages, 8 figures. Author's version of Paper 13899-47 presented at SPIE Photonics West Advanced Fabrication Technologies for Micro/Nano Optics and Photonics XIX, January 2026. To appear in SPIE Proceedings Vol. 13899
summary: Two-photon polymerization (2PP) enables fabrication of high-precision micro-optics with complex freeform geometries, opening a new parameter space for custom astronomical optics. Among available resins, the newly developed IPX Clear is particularly well suited for visible applications, offering high transmission across the visible-near-IR, low surface roughness, and excellent shape fidelity. However, Fresnel reflections at the air-polymer interface introduce significant optical losses, which are detrimental in low-signal astronomy. Previous studies show grass-like alumina coatings on glass and fused silica can raise average transmission from 91.9% to approximately 99% over 400-900 nm. Here we explore the feasibility of Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) to apply such coatings to IPX-Clear micro-optics over 400-1700 nm. Grass-like alumina anti-reflective (AR) coatings can approximate the ideal index condition by creating a gradual refractive-index transition from air to bulk IPX Clear, suppressing surface reflections. While grass-like coatings are established on bulk optics and conformal ALD films have been applied to 2PP micro-optics, we demonstrate - for the first time - alumina grass on 2PP microlenses made with the new IPX-Clear resin. We discuss key challenges and process steps, and observe that alumina-grass-coated microlenses lose only approximately 0.3% of photons to reflection in the 400-850 nm range. Future work will test performance across the full 400-1700 nm band and explore improved environmental resilience, e.g., a SiO2 overcoat. Combined with the high optical transparency of IPX Clear, these coatings enable custom-designed, highly efficient microlenses for astronomical applications.

AI.tldr: This paper demonstrates the application of grass-like alumina anti-reflective coatings via Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) onto 2PP-fabricated IPX-Clear microlenses, achieving 99.7% transmission efficiency in visible wavelengths and addressing optical losses for astronomical applications.
AI.motivation: To enhance transmission efficiency of 2PP micro-optics in low-signal astronomical applications where Fresnel reflections are problematic. Existing grass-like alumina coatings improved transmission on bulk optics, so the study adapts this to novel IPX-Clear resin microlenses.
AI.method: Fabricated IPX-Clear microlenses using 2PP. Applied grass-like alumina AR coatings via ALD to create a refractive-index gradient between air and polymer. Tested reflection losses in 400-850 nm range.
AI.result: Coated microlenses lost only ~0.3% photons due to reflection (99.7% transmission), outperforming uncoated versions. Validated feasibility but noted challenges in ALD uniformity and environmental durability.
AI.conclusion: ALD-applied alumina grass coatings successfully minimize reflection losses on 2PP microlenses, opening potential for custom high-efficiency astronomical optics. Further work required to optimize for full spectral range and durability.

title: Cyclotron lines in subcritical X-ray pulsars: Monte Carlo simulations reveal the origin of the observed variability
comment: 14 pages, 11 figures, 2 tables. Submitted for publication to A&A
summary: Observed cyclotron resonant scattering features (CRSFs) in X-ray pulsars (XRPs) exhibit strong variability. In the subcritical luminosity regime, the centroid energy ($E_{CRSF}$) and line width ($σ_{CRSF}$) often show positive correlations with the X-ray luminosity. We investigate the physical origin of the observed variability quantitatively, focusing on the effects of resonant scattering and Doppler shift induced by the plasma flow in the accretion funnel. We developed a relativistic Monte Carlo code to perform detailed radiative transfer calculations in the accretion funnel above the hotspot and derive angle-dependent spectra. Analytical plasma density and velocity profiles were adopted to account for the effects of radiation pressure on the flow. Approximate resonant scattering cross-sections were employed. We varied the accretion luminosity to explore the resulting variability of the CRSF properties. The emergent spectra exhibit a prominent, asymmetric CRSF accompanied by a broad blue wing. The CRSF is systematically redshifted relative to the classical cyclotron energy, with the magnitude of the redshift decreasing at higher luminosities and for larger viewing angles $θ$. Both $E_{CRSF}$ and $σ_{CRSF}$ correlate positively with luminosity for all viewing angles. Their absolute values, however, depend strongly on the viewing angle, indicating substantial variability over the pulse cycle and sensitivity to the system geometry. At fixed luminosity, $E_{CRSF}$ ($σ_{CRSF}$) decreases (increases) with increasing $\cosθ$. Consequently, phase-resolved observations are expected to reveal an anticorrelation between the CRSF centroid energy and width. When applied to the XRP GX 304$-$1, the model reproduces the observed CRSF variability over nearly an order of magnitude in luminosity for geometries in which the accretion funnel is predominantly viewed edge-on.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates variability in cyclotron resonant scattering features (CRSFs) of X-ray pulsars, showing positive correlations between CRSF centroid energy and width with luminosity. Using a relativistic Monte Carlo model, they find CRSF properties depend on accretion luminosity and viewing angle, predicting anticorrelation between CRSF energy and width in phase-resolved observations.
AI.motivation: To understand the physical origins of observed variability in CRSF parameters (E_CRSF and σ_CRSF) linked to X-ray luminosity in subcritical XRPs.
AI.method: Developed a relativistic Monte Carlo radiative transfer code simulating accretion funnel spectra, incorporating plasma density/velocity profiles affected by radiation pressure and approximate resonant scattering cross-sections. Varyed luminosity to study effects on CRSF properties.
AI.result: CRSFs show systematic redshift relative to classical cyclotron energy; E_CRSF/σ_CRSF positively correlate with luminosity but depend strongly on viewing angle θ.
