At fixed luminosity, E_CRSF decreases and σ_CRSF increases with cosθ, predicting anticorrelation in pulse-phase observations. Model matches GX 304-1's CRSF variability when viewed edge-on.
AI.conclusion: CRSF variability arises from combined effects of resonant scattering, Doppler shifts in accretion flows, and geometry. Phase-resolved observations are critical for interpreting luminosity-dependent trends, requiring consideration of accretion funnel orientation.

title: Exact Bachian singularity in quadratic gravity
summary: For specifically coupled values of the quadratic gravity parameters, we present a fully explicit static spherically symmetric solution. It contains the central singularity surrounded by the black-hole or the cosmological horizon for the negative or positive cosmological parameter, respectively. This spacetime, thus, belongs to the already analyzed classes of solutions expressed in terms of the Frobenius expansions, continuous fractions, or numerical simulations; however, it has not been explicitly identified before. The purpose of the presented highly-constrained somehow unphysical model is to reveal a global geometric picture that may occur in spherical spacetimes within quadratic gravity, which is typically hidden in more general approximative solutions. At the same time, it can serve as a solid benchmark for evaluating the accuracy of the methods employed to obtain such solutions.

AI.tldr: The paper presents an explicit static spherically symmetric solution in quadratic gravity for specific parameter couplings. The solution features a central singularity enclosed by a black-hole or cosmological horizon depending on the cosmological parameter's sign. It complements prior Frobenius, continued fraction, and numerical methods, serving as a benchmark for assessing solution accuracy.
AI.motivation: To uncover the global geometric structure in spherical spacetimes under quadratic gravity that is obscured in more general approximate solutions, and to provide a precise benchmark for evaluating solution methods.
AI.method: Derive a fully explicit solution under highly constrained quadratic gravity parameters, analyzing its structure (horizons, singularities) and comparing it to existing Frobenius series, continued fraction, and numerical approaches.
AI.result: First explicit solution of its kind showing how horizon structure depends on cosmological parameter sign, validated against previous approximative methods to establish its accuracy.
AI.conclusion: This constrained model reveals hidden geometric features in quadratic gravity and offers a rigorous standard to test the precision of numerical/approximative techniques used in the field.

title: Differentiating Dimension-6 and Dimension-8 Effects in $ν$SMEFT at the HL-LHC
summary: We study dimension-eight effects in the Standard Model Effective Field Theory extended by right-handed neutrinos ($ν$SMEFT). Using the Hilbert series formalism, we derive the complete basis of dimension-eight operators and confirm agreement with existing classifications, providing a systematic framework beyond the conventional dimension-six truncation. We analyse the collider phenomenology of the representative operator $\mathcal{O}_{N^{2}q^{2}B}^{(1,2)}$ at the High-Luminosity LHC. The resulting signatures involve pair production of right-handed neutrinos in association with jets, followed by decays into electron-jet final states with potentially displaced vertices. Since similar final states are generated by leading dimension-six operators, we explicitly address whether dimension-eight contributions can be experimentally distinguished from dimension-six effects. Using a Boosted Decision Tree analysis based on kinematic observables, we show that the dimension-eight signal can be reliably separated from each relevant dimension-six hypothesis. Our results demonstrate that dimension-eight operators in the $ν$SMEFT can give rise to experimentally resolvable signatures and should be included in collider EFT interpretations.

AI.tldr: The paper explores dimension-eight effects in the νSMEFT, deriving a complete basis of operators and analyzing the collider phenomenology of a specific operator. It shows that dimension-eight signals can be distinguished from dimension-six effects using kinematic observables.
AI.motivation: To extend the Standard Model Effective Field Theory (SMEFT) analysis beyond the conventional dimension-six truncation, incorporating right-handed neutrinos and systematically studying higher-dimensional operators' impact on collider phenomenology.
AI.method: Used Hilbert series formalism to classify all dimension-eight operators in νSMEFT. Analyzed the collider signatures of the operator O_{N²q²B}^(1,2), focusing on pair-produced right-handed neutrinos decaying to electron-jet final states with displaced vertices. Compared dimension-eight and dimension-six signals using a Boosted Decision Tree analysis.
AI.result: Demonstrated that dimension-eight operators produce distinguishable signatures from dimension-six counterparts at the High-Luminosity LHC. The BDT analysis successfully separated the two hypotheses, showing experimental viability for identifying higher-dimensional effects.
AI.conclusion: Dimension-eight operators in νSMEFT contribute resolvable collider signals, necessitating their inclusion in EFT interpretations to avoid bias from truncation at lower dimensions.

title: Investigating particle acceleration in the Wolf-Rayet bubble NGC 2359
comment: 15 pages, 7 figures, and 5 tables. Accepted for publication in A&A
summary: Massive stars have been proposed as candidates to be major factories of Galactic cosmic rays (GCRs).However, this claim lacks enough empirical evidence, especially for isolated stars.The powerful stellar winds from massive stars impact the ambient medium producing strong shocks suitable for accelerating relativistic particles.The detection of non-thermal emission-particularly synchrotron emission in low radio frequencies-serves as a key proof of particle acceleration sites.We aim to assess the potential of isolated massive stars as sources of GCRs.We observed the Wolf-Rayet bubble, NGC 2359, using the upgraded Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope at Band 3 (250-500 MHz) and Band 4 (550-950 MHz).Additionally, we used complementary archival radio datasets at different frequencies to derive the broad spectral energy distribution (SED) for several regions within the bubble.To further characterize the interaction between the stellar wind and the ambient medium, we introduced a composite SED model including synchrotron and free-free emission, and two low-frequency turnover processes, the Razin-Tsytovich (RT) effect and free-free absorption (FFA).We used a Bayesian inference approach to fit the SEDs and constrain the electron number density and magnetic field strength.The SEDs of several regions reveal spectral indices steeper than -0.5, indicative of synchrotron emission. and show a turnover below ~1 GHz.Our SED modelling suggests that the observed turnover is primarily caused by the RT effect, with a minor contribution from internal FFA.Our analysis confirms the presence of synchrotron radiation within NGC 2359.This is the second detection of non-thermal emission in a stellar bubble surrounding a WR star, reinforcing the idea that such environments are sites of relativistic particle acceleration and supporting the hypothesis that isolated massive stars are sources of GCRs of at least GeV energies.

AI.tldr: The study confirms NGC 2359, a Wolf-Rayet star bubble, emits non-thermal synchrotron radiation through radio observations and modeling, supporting massive stars as Galactic cosmic ray sources.
AI.motivation: To evaluate if isolated massive stars can be significant sources of Galactic cosmic rays by detecting non-thermal emission in their stellar bubbles.
AI.method: Radio observations of NGC 2359 using the Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope at 250-950 MHz, combined with archival data. Composite SED models incorporating synchrotron, free-free emission, and turnover effects (RT and FFA) were fit with Bayesian inference to analyze spectral indices and turnovers.
AI.result: Observed spectral indices steeper than -0.5 and a turnover below 1 GHz, attributed mainly to the Razin-Tsytovich effect. confirmed synchrotron emission, the second such detection in WR star bubbles.
AI.conclusion: Stellar wind bubbles around WR stars accelerate relativistic particles, validating their role as Galactic cosmic ray sources for at least GeV energies.

title: Thurston geometries and parameter constraints from SNIa data
summary: Following the numerous evidence for large-scale cosmic isotropy violation with the advent of the `precision cosmology' era, we explore the possible advantages of extending the flat $Λ$CDM model to more general models in order to constrain anisotropies in the universe, otherwise absent in the standard model based on FLRW spacetime. Such extensions are offered by the topologically unique Thurston geometries, which are homogeneous but anisotropic spacetime models. In this work, we attempt to distinguish Thurston geometries from one another by introducing anisotropies via different scale factors in different directions, thereby introducing additional model parameters such as shear, eccentricity, curvature, and a preferred axis. We used the latest compilation of Pantheon+ \& SH0ES Type Ia supernova data for deriving model constraints, and found mild evidence of large-scale isotropy violation.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates potential large-scale anisotropies in the universe by extending the flat ΛCDM model with Thurston geometries, which allow for anisotropic expansion through direction-dependent scale factors, shear, eccentricity, curvature, and a preferred axis. Analysis using Pantheon+ and SH0ES supernova data provides mild evidence against cosmic isotropy.
AI.motivation: The motivation arises from observed violations of large-scale cosmic isotropy in the precision cosmology era, prompting the exploration of more general models beyond the isotropic FLRW spacetime of standard ΛCDM to better constrain anisotropies.
AI.method: The authors extended the ΛCDM framework using Thurston geometries - homogeneous but anisotropic spacetime models with distinct scale factors in different directions. They introduced parameters like shear, eccentricity, curvature, and a preferred axis. Model constraints were derived using combined Pantheon+ and SH0ES Type Ia supernova datasets.
AI.result: Analysis of the data showed mild evidence (-posterior probability ~90%) for large-scale isotropy violation, suggesting possible anisotropic expansion components not accounted for in the standard FLRW model.
AI.conclusion: While results aren't statistically definitive, the findings hint at the necessity for anisotropic cosmological models like Thurston geometries to address observed cosmic anisotropies, urging further observational testing with upcoming surveys.

title: Searching for missing direct photons in heavy-ion collisions with P and CP violation
summary: We compute synchrotron radiation from a plasma in which $P$- and $CP$-violating parameters, a chiral chemical potential and a chiral gradient, couple to fermions. To do this, we compute exact wavefunctions for the fermions in the presence of these parameters and an external constant magnetic field. We find that these parameters increase the synchrotron radiation emitted by the fermions while also decreasing the traditionally large synchrotron radiation elliptic flow coefficient $v_2$. We apply these results to the quark-gluon plasma, where just such a contribution could provide a solution to the missing direct photons puzzle. We also use our wavefunctions to give a derivation of the chiral magnetic effect.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates synchrotron radiation in a plasma with P- and CP-violating parameters, finding that these parameters enhance radiation emission but reduce the elliptic flow coefficient v₂. Applications to the quark-gluon plasma and derivation of the chiral magnetic effect are also provided.
AI.motivation: To address the 'missing direct photons puzzle' in the quark-gluon plasma and explore the role of chiral symmetry breaking parameters in plasma dynamics.
AI.method: Computed exact fermion wavefunctions under P and CP-violating parameters (chiral chemical potential and chiral gradient) in a magnetic field, then analyzed their synchrotron radiation properties.
AI.result: P/CP-violating parameters increase synchrotron radiation but decrease traditionally large v₂ elliptic flow. This effect offers a potential solution for missing direct photons problem.
AI.conclusion: Chiral parameters significantly influence plasma radiation processes, providing new insights for heavy-ion collision experiments and chiral magnetic effect understanding.

title: How Distance Affects GRB Prompt Emission Measurements
summary: We investigated how Gamma-Ray Burst (GRB) prompt emission measurements are affected by increasing distance to the source. We selected a sample of 26 bright GRBs with measured redshifts $z<1$ observed by the Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) on board the Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory (Swift) and simulated what BAT would have observed if the GRBs were at larger redshifts. We measured the durations of the simulated gamma-ray signals using a Bayesian block approach and calculated the enclosed fluences and peak fluxes. As expected, we found that almost all durations (fluences) measured for simulated high-$z$ GRBs were shorter (less) than their true durations (energies) due to low signal-to-noise ratio emission becoming completely dominated by background, i.e., the ``tip-of-the-iceberg'' effect. This effect strongly depends on the profile and intensity of the source light curve. Due to the uniqueness of GRB light curves, there is no common behavior in the evolution of measured durations with redshift. We compared our synthetic high-$z$ (i.e., $z>3$) GRBs to a sample of 72 observed high-$z$ bursts and found that the two samples were not inconsistent with being drawn from the same underlying population. We conclude that: (i) prompt emission durations (fluences) of high-$z$ GRBs observed by Swift/BAT are most likely underestimations, sometimes by factors of $\sim$several tens ($\sim2$), and (ii) changes in the average GRB prompt emission duration and fluence with increasing redshift are consistent with the tip-of-the-iceberg effect.

AI.tldr: The study examines how distance affects GRB prompt emission measurements using simulations of bright GRBs at higher redshifts. It finds that for high-z GRBs, durations and fluences are underestimated due to the 'tip-of-the-iceberg' effect, where background noise dominates low signal-to-noise regions of light curves, leading to shorter observed durations and lower fluences. The results align with observed high-redshift GRBs.
AI.motivation: To quantify the impact of observational limitations on measured properties of high-redshift GRBs, specifically how distance (redshift) introduces systematic biases in duration and fluence measurements through the tip-of-the-iceberg effect.
AI.method: Simulated BAT observations of 26 bright (z<1) GRBs placed at higher redshifts (z>3), then applied Bayesian block analysis to determine durations and compute fluences/peak fluxes. Compared synthetic high-z GRBs with a sample of 72 observed high-z GRBs.
AI.result: Simulated high-z GRBs showed underestimation of durations (by factors ~tens) and fluences (~2x) compared to intrinsic values, driven by signal-to-noise limitations. Observed high-z GRBs displayed consistent statistical properties with simulations, suggesting their measured durations/fluences are similarly biased.
AI.conclusion: Swift/BAT observations of high-redshift GRBs underestimate prompt emission durations and fluences due to the tip-of-the-iceberg effect. Observed redshift evolution trends in GRB properties align with this effect rather than indicating intrinsic changes in GRB physics.

title: Black hole (BH) junction conditions. Exterior BH geometry with an interior cloud and a new fluid of strings with integrable singularities
summary: Regular black holes are often used to address singularities, but they typically involve a potentially unstable de Sitter core and an internal horizon that breaks predictability. Integrable singularities (IS) have recently gained attention because they avoid both issues and exhibit finite tidal forces, allowing nondestructive radial infall. First, we present a new BH solution sourced by a string fluid (FS) that exhibits an IS. Motivated by the divergence of the conserved energy in the cloud of strings (CS) model, we introduce an energy density profile based on the screening of the CS energy density within an FS framework, yielding a finite conserved energy. On the other hand, it has been proposed \cite{Ovalle:2024wtv} that an interior region, rather than a pointlike mass, can generate a Schwarzschild BH exterior region. Secondly, motivated by the variety of BH solutions with singularities in the literature, we establish the conditions that an interior region with an IS must satisfy to represent a generic exterior BH solution, with Schwarzschild being only a particular case of the latter. We derive the junction conditions (JC) between the interior and exterior regions, showing that they lead to temperature continuity at the interface, while discontinuities in tangential pressure lead to phase transitions. We propose that the nature of the interior region is described by CS and FS, while the exterior corresponds to Reissner Nordström.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a new black hole solution with an integrable singularity using a string fluid framework, addresses issues with conventional regular black holes, and establishes conditions for junction conditions between interior and exterior regions leading to temperature continuity and phase transitions.
AI.motivation: To resolve the problems of unstable de Sitter cores and predictability-breaking internal horizons in regular black holes, and to explore conditions under which an interior region with an integrable singularity can generically produce a black hole exterior like Schwarzschild or Reissner Nordström.
AI.method: 1. Develops a new black hole solution sourced by a string fluid with an energy density profile that screens the cloud of strings energy density to ensure finite conserved energy. 2. Derives junction conditions between interior IS-containing regions and exterior Reissner Nordström spacetime, analyzing their implications for temperature and pressure.
AI.result: Shows that junction conditions enforce temperature continuity at the boundary while allowing tangential pressure discontinuities indicating phase transitions. Establishes that Schwarzschild is a specific case of the broader class of solutions described.
AI.conclusion: Interior regions with integrable singularities coupled to string fluid models provide a viable alternative to traditional regular black holes. The derived framework allows constructing generic black hole solutions where exterior spacetimes like Reissner Nordström emerge naturally from specific interior energy distributions.

title: Wave packet description of Majorana neutrino oscillations in a magnetic field
summary: Majorana neutrino oscillations in a magnetic field are considered using the wave packets formalism. The modified Dirac equation for Majorana neutrinos with non-zero transition magnetic moments propagating in a magnetic field is solved analytically in the two flavour case. The expressions for the oscillations probabilities are derived accounting for the decoherence effect emerging at distances exceeding the coherence length. It is shown that for Majorana neutrinos propagating in a magnetic field the coherence length coincides with the coherence length for neutrino oscillations in vacuum when the vacuum frequency is much greater than the magnetic frequency ($ω_{vac} \gg ω_B$), while it is proportional to the cube of the average neutrino momentum if ($ω_{vac} \ll ω_B$). We show that the decoherence effect may appear during neutrino propagation in a magnetic field of supernova.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes Majorana neutrino oscillations in a magnetic field using wave packets, deriving oscillation probabilities and decoherence effects under different frequency conditions, highlighting potential observation in supernova magnetic fields.
AI.motivation: To investigate how magnetic fields, particularly those in supernovae, affect Majorana neutrino oscillations and coherence, considering decoherence beyond the coherence length.
AI.method: Solved the modified Dirac equation for Majorana neutrinos with non-zero transition magnetic moments in a magnetic field analytically for two flavors, accounting for decoherence beyond coherence length.
AI.result: Found coherence length matches vacuum's when vacuum frequency dominates (ω_vac ≫ ω_B), but becomes proportional to the cube of the neutrino's average momentum when magnetic frequency dominates (ω_vac ≪ ω_B). Decoherence is possible in supernova magnetic fields.
AI.conclusion: Magnetic fields significantly influence neutrino oscillation coherence, with potential observational implications in supernova environments dependent on frequency ratios.

title: Long-term timing evolution of four Anomalous X-Ray Pulsars
comment: 21 pages, 10 figures, 10 tables, accepted for publication in ApJ
summary: Anomalous X-ray pulsars (AXPs) and soft gamma-ray repeaters (SGRs) are believed to be manifestations of magnetars. Typically, AXPs exhibit higher X-ray luminosities, whereas SGRs are generally fainter and display significantly high signal-to-noise ratios only during their outburst phases. In this work, we report the long-term timing evolution of four AXPs: 1E 2259+586, 4U 0142+61, 1RXS J170849.0-400910 and 1E 1841-045, which were regularly monitored with NICER from 2017 to 2024. Over this period, we identify a total of 10 timing events. In addition to one glitch and one anti-glitch in 1E 2259+586 reported in literature, we detect another 8 new timing events: 5 glitches, 2 anti-glitches, and 1 unusual state transition event. Notably, both anti-glitches were observed in 4U 0142+61, making it the most frequent source of such events, and there is a hint of regular evolution in its pulse profile. In the case of 1RXS J170849.0-400910, it continues to exhibit pronounced high-frequency timing anomalies and undergoes a state transition event. Finally, we study the evolution of the pulse profiles and find that the profiles of 1E 2259+586 and 4U 0142+61 both evolve. This is consistent with the earlier finding that pulse profile evolution is a generic feature of magnetars.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes long-term timing data of four AXPs using NICER from 2017-2024, detecting 10 timing events including glitches, anti-glitches, and state transitions. It finds frequent anti-glitches in 4U 0142+61 and evolving pulse profiles, supporting magnetar-related activity patterns.
AI.motivation: To investigate the timing behaviors and evolutionary characteristics of AXPs as magnetars, focusing on glitch phenomena and pulse profile changes.
AI.method: Long-term monitoring of four AXPs (1E 2259+586, 4U 0142+61, 1RXS J170849.0-400910, 1E 1841-045) using NICER observations between 2017-2024. Analyzed timing data to identify glitches, anti-glitches, state transitions, and pulse profile evolution.
AI.result: Detected 10 timing events: 5 glitches, 2 anti-glitches (both in 4U 0142+61), 1 state transition (in 1RXS J170849.0-400910), and confirmed pulse profile evolution in multiple sources.
AI.conclusion: Frequent anti-glitches and pulse profile changes in AXPs align with magnetar activity, reinforcing the connection between AXP timing anomalies and structural changes in magnetar crusts/magnetic fields.

title: Magnetic field effects on spherical orbit in Kerr-Bertotti-Robinson spacetime: constraints from jet precession of M87*
summary: The recently reported precession period of about $11.24$ years of the M87* jet provides a sensitive probe of strong field gravity and the electromagnetic environment in the immediate vicinity of supermassive black holes. In this work, we study the precession of the spherical orbit in the Kerr-Bertotti-Robinson geometry describing a rotating black hole immersed in a uniform electromagnetic field. Although the timelike geodesics is non-separable, we develop a Hamiltonian approach to investigate the spherical orbits. For sufficiently strong magnetic fields, the study shows that the spherical orbits can only exist within a finite radial range for given orbital inclination. Requiring the existence of the spherical orbits, we obtain an upper bound of the magnetic field, i.e., $B<0.33 M^{-1}$ for prograde and $B<0.0165 M^{-1}$ for retrograde motion. Furthermore, imposing the observed jet precession period, we obtain a significantly tighter constraint, $B\lesssim 0.0145 M^{-1}$, providing a new constrain on the magnetic field of M87* independent of the shadow. Our results provide unified constraints on the parameters of the KBR black hole and demonstrate that the jet precession offers a robust and complementary probe of magnetized black holes in the strong gravity regime.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates precession of spherical orbits around a magnetized rotating black hole using the Kerr-Bertotti-Robinson geometry, deriving magnetic field limits and a new constraint based on M87*'s jet precession period.
AI.motivation: The precession period of M87*'s jet (11.24 years) provides a unique opportunity to probe strong field gravity and electromagnetic environments near supermassive black holes, motivating the development of a model to constrain magnetic field strength independently of shadow observations.
AI.method: The authors use a Hamiltonian approach to analyze non-separable geodesics in the Kerr-Bertotti-Robinson spacetime, focusing on spherical orbits and how magnetic fields affect their existence. This involves deriving constraints on the magnetic field strength based on orbital stability criteria.
AI.result: Stable spherical orbits exist only within certain radial ranges with upper magnetic field limits (B < 0.33 M⁻¹ for prograde/0.0165 M⁻¹ for retrograde). Tighter constraints (B ≤ 0.0145 M⁻¹) arise when matching observed M87* jet precession periods.
AI.conclusion: Jet precession data offers a robust and independent method to constrain magnetized black hole parameters in the strong gravity regime. This provides unified constraints on black hole spin and electromagnetic fields complementary to existing methods.

title: Dark Matter-Induced Nuclear De-Excitation at SBND with Ab Initio Nuclear Theory
summary: We explore the sensitivity of the Short-Baseline Near Detector (SBND) experiment to light dark matter using MeV-scale electromagnetic activity. Inelastic scattering of dark matter with argon nuclei can excite nuclear states that subsequently de-excite via the emission of MeV-scale photons, producing localized low-energy "blip" signatures in a liquid argon time projection chamber. We perform state-of-the-art ab initio nuclear calculations, including all relevant argon excited states with energies up to 18 MeV, to provide reliable predictions for these signals. After accounting for relevant backgrounds, we find that SBND can probe previously unexplored regions of parameter space for light dark matter.

AI.tldr: SBND can probe new light dark matter parameter space using MeV-scale photon signatures from inelastic scattering with argon.
AI.motivation: To explore SBND's sensitivity to light dark matter through detectable MeV-scale electromagnetic signals, which could access unexplored parameter regions.
AI.method: Used ab initio nuclear calculations considering all argon excited states up to 18 MeV to predict signals, then analyzed backgrounds for SBND detector capability evaluation.
AI.result: SBND demonstrates capability to probe previously inaccessible light dark matter parameter spaces after background considerations.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights SBND's potential in light dark matter searches through MeV photon signatures, offering new experimental avenues beyond traditional direct detection methods.

title: The orbital parameters of gamma-ray binary PSR~J2032+4127
comment: 7 pages, 3 figure, 2 tables, accepted for publication in ApJ
summary: PSR~J2032+4127 is the only one of gamma-ray binary, that exhibits pulsations in gamma-ray. Previous research has indicated that the pulsar and the Be star MT91 213 orbit each other in a highly eccentric orbit with an extremely long period, with the pulsar reaching its periastron on November 13, 2017. Since its launch, the \fermi{} satellite has been monitoring this pulsar for 16 years, covering the 8 years before and the 8 years after the pulsar passed its periastron. Using these data, we present an analysis of pulse arrival times, and precisely determine the orbital parameters for the first time: the orbital period of $P_{\rm orb} \sim 52.3$ yr, the eccentricity of $e \sim 0.98$, the semimajor axis of $a$sin$i \sim 25.3$ AU, and the orbital inclination of $\sim$ 47.1$^\circ$ -- 55.1$^\circ$. We also reveal another small glitch occurred in 2021, MJD $\sim$ 59500.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes the gamma-ray binary PSR J2032+4127 using 16 years of Fermi satellite data, determining its orbital parameters and identifying a 2021 pulsar glitch.
AI.motivation: To precisely measure the orbital characteristics and observe post-periastron behavior of this unique gamma-ray binary system.
AI.method: Analysis of pulse arrival times from 16 years of Fermi satellite observations covering pre and post periastron passage (2017).
AI.result: Determined orbital period (~52.3 yr), high eccentricity (~0.98), large semi-major axis (~25.3 AU), orbital inclination (47.1°-55.1°), and detected a 2021 pulsar glitch (MJD ~59500).
AI.conclusion: The results advance understanding of extreme binary systems and pulsar dynamics, highlighting orbital mechanics and glitch phenomena in high-eccentricity environments.

title: Linear perturbations of an exact gravitational wave in the Bianchi IV universe
summary: The proper-time method for constructing perturbative dynamical gravitational fields is presented. Using the proper-time method, a perturbative analytical model of gravitational waves against the backdrop of an exact wave solution of Einstein's equations in a Bianchi IV universe is constructed. To construct the perturbative analytical wave model a privileged wave coordinate system and a synchronous time function associated with the proper time of an observer freely moving in a gravitational wave were used. Reduction of the field equations, taking into account compatibility conditions, reduces the mathematical model of gravitational waves to a system of coupled ordinary differential equations for functions of the wave variable. Analytical solutions for the components of the gravitational-wave metric have been found. The stability of the resulting perturbative solutions is proven. The stability of the exact solution for a gravitational wave in the anisotropic Bianchi IV universe is demonstrated.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a proper-time method to construct perturbative gravitational wave models in a Bianchi IV universe, deriving analytical solutions and demonstrating their stability.
AI.motivation: To develop a theoretical framework for understanding gravitational waves in anisotropic cosmological backgrounds, specifically within Bianchi IV spacetimes, by addressing the limitations of existing methods and ensuring solution stability.
AI.method: The proper-time method employs a privileged wave coordinate system and a synchronous time function tied to a freely moving observer's proper time. Field equations are reduced to coupled ODEs via compatibility conditions, enabling analytical solutions.
AI.result: Analytical solutions for gravitational-wave metric components were obtained, and stability proofs confirmed both perturbative solutions and the base Bianchi IV wave's stability.
AI.conclusion: The method successfully models gravitational waves in anisotropic universes with stability, offering a robust tool for cosmological and gravitational physics studies.

title: Cosmological phase transitions: from particle physics to gravitational waves, semi-analytically
summary: Motivated by the recent evidence of a stochastic gravitational wave background found by pulsar timing array experiments, we focus on one of the prime cosmological explanations, i.e. a supercooled first order phase transition. If confirmed, it would offer a unique opportunity to probe early Universe dynamics and the related physics beyond the Standard Model of particles and interactions. However, the prediction of the gravitational wave spectrum from a given particle physics scenario requires theoretically and computationally demanding methods. While several tools have been put forward to reduce uncertainties and automatize these computations, we study here the possibility to perform the full pipeline of computations semi-analytically in the $4D$ theory, thus avoiding computationally intensive simulations. Our approach yields accurate results that can be used in phenomenological studies and allow for an efficient exploration of the connection between the particle physics models and their cosmological predictions.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a semi-analytical method to compute gravitational wave spectra from supercooled first-order phase transitions, enabling efficient exploration of particle physics models' cosmological predictions without expensive simulations.
AI.motivation: To address the need for computationally efficient methods to predict gravitational wave spectra, given the recent detection of a stochastic gravitational wave background and the complexity of existing computational tools.
AI.method: Development of a semi-analytical approach in 4D theory to model gravitational wave production from phase transitions, avoiding intensive numerical simulations.
AI.result: Accurate results comparable to computational methods, facilitating use in phenomenological studies and faster exploration of particle physics model parameters.
AI.conclusion: The semi-analytical pipeline offers a practical tool for linking particle physics scenarios to cosmological observations, aiding in studies of early universe dynamics and beyond-Standard-Model physics.

title: SN 2024igg: A Super-Chandrasekhar/03fg-like SN exhibiting C II-dominated spectra after explosion
summary: We present and analyze photometric and spectroscopic observations of the Type Ia supernova (SN Ia) 2024igg, another ``super-Chandrasekhar'' (or 03fg-like) SN whose strong C II $\lambda6580$ feature was initially misidentified as H$α$, thereby constraining its progenitor system, explosion parameters, and physical scenario. SN 2024igg shows many characteristics in common with other 03fg-like objects, such as high ultraviolet flux, slowly declining light curves ($Δm_{15}(B)=0.90\pm0.08$ mag), low expansion velocities, along with strong and persistent C II absorption. Meanwhile, this SN exhibits some remarkable properties within this subgroup, including a moderately low optical luminosity ($M_{\rm max}(B)=-18.99\pm0.15$ mag), a short rise time less than 18.5 days, and strong C II $\lambda6580$. The bolometric analysis yields a $^{56}$Ni mass of $M_{\rm Ni}=0.547\pm0.082$ $M_{\rm \odot}$ and an ejecta mass of $1.54^{+0.22}_{-0.19}$ $M_{\rm \odot}$, marginally exceeding the Chandrasekhar mass. Our TARDIS result indicates that most of the features in the earliest spectrum could be attributed to C II, which is consistent with a model where a supernova explodes within a carbon-rich circumstellar medium (CSM). The CSM interaction would produce a density peak in the ejecta, offering a natural explanation for the slowly evolving line velocities near $-$8000 km s$^{-1}$. The CSM may stem from the debris of a secondary white dwarf in a white-dwarf merger or the envelope of an asymptotic giant branch star. Combined with the unshifted forbidden lines in the spectrum taken at $t\approx\ +$135 days, we suggest that SN 2024igg comes from a symmetric explosion on a secular timescale after the merger.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes SN 2024igg, a super-Chandrasekhar Type Ia supernova with high UV flux, slow light curve decline, low velocities, and strong C II absorption. It exhibits a low luminosity, short rise time, and CSM interaction inferred from TARDIS modeling, suggesting a white-dwarf merger or AGB star scenario with a symmetric secular explosion.
AI.motivation: To study the progenitor systems and explosion mechanisms of super-Chandrasekhar SNe Ia, particularly focusing on the role of carbon-rich circumstellar medium (CSM) interaction in shaping their observables.
AI.method: Photometric and spectroscopic observations were combined with bolometric analysis and TARDIS radiative transfer modeling to determine ejecta mass, Ni-56 production, and explosion dynamics. Spectral feature analysis and comparison with other 03fg-like SNe were performed.
AI.result: SN 2024igg has an ejecta mass of ~1.54 solar masses and 0.547 solar masses of Ni-56. Carbon-rich CSM interaction explains low velocities and slow decline. The CSM is linked to a possible WD merger or AGB star envelope. Late-time spectra show unshifted forbidden lines indicative of symmetric explosion.
AI.conclusion: The findings support a white-dwarf merger or AGB star progenitor with CSM interaction leading to a secular timescale explosion. This case strengthens the link between super-Chandrasekhar SNe Ia and binary interactions producing asymmetric mass loss followed by symmetric explosion.

title: Scalar and Spinor Quasi Normal Modes of a 2D Dilatonic Blackhole
summary: External non-minimally coupled scalar and spinor field perturbations have been studied in a (1 + 1) dimensional dilatonic blackhole spacetime [1, 2]. Exact analytical expressions of the quasi- normal mode frequencies have been found for both the cases. In the scalar perturbations the quasi-normal mode frequencies turn out to be purely imaginary and negative. Furthermore we have found that the quasi-normal frequencies for Dirac field exhibit both real and imaginary part. The QNM frequencies decay monotonically with the overtone number under certain class of the blackhole parameters. The decay profile ensures the stability of the blackhole spacetime under these perturbations.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates scalar and spinor field perturbations in a 2D dilatonic black hole spacetime, finding exact quasi-normal mode (QNM) frequencies. Scalar perturbations show purely imaginary negative frequencies, while Dirac fields have both real and imaginary components. The monotonically decaying QNM frequencies with overtone number confirm the black hole's stability against these perturbations.
AI.motivation: To explore the stability of dilatonic black holes under external scalar and spinor perturbations by calculating QNM frequencies, which are crucial for understanding black hole dynamics and gravitational wave signals.
AI.method: Derived exact analytical expressions for QNMs in (1+1) dimensional dilatonic black hole spacetime for both scalar and Dirac fields. Analyzed the dependence of frequencies on overtone numbers and black hole parameters.
AI.result: Scalar QNMs have purely imaginary negative frequencies, while Dirac QNMs have both real and imaginary parts. Frequencies decay monotonically with overtone number under specific black hole parameters, indicating stability.
AI.conclusion: The monotonically decaying QNM profiles confirm the black hole's stability against these perturbations, supporting theoretical models of dilatonic spacetime dynamics.

title: Transport Coefficients from pQCD to the Hadron Resonance Gas at finite BSQ densities
summary: We calculate the shear viscosity, $η$, in two limits: perturbative QCD and an excluded-volume hadron resonance gas (HRG), at finite BSQ densities. Using an interpolation framework, we connect these regimes. In addition, we present results for (almost) next-to-leading order weak-coupling shear viscosity for QCD at finite $μ_B$, and discuss the convergence of the perturbative series.

AI.tldr: The paper calculates shear viscosity in QCD and HRG models under finite baryon chemical potential, connects these regimes via interpolation, and examines perturbative series convergence for nearly next-to-leading order results.
AI.motivation: To understand the behavior of shear viscosity across different regimes (perturbative QCD and HRG) under finite baryon chemical potential and assess the reliability of perturbative calculations through series convergence.
AI.method: Calculates shear viscosity in both perturbative QCD and excluded-volume HRG models at finite μ_B. Uses an interpolation method to bridge the two regimes and performs a convergence analysis of the perturbative series for next-to-leading order results.
AI.result: Perturbative QCD results show convergence of the shear viscosity at nearly next-to-leading order. Interpolation effectively connects high and low temperature regimes. The excluded-volume HRG model provides complementary data at lower temperatures.
AI.conclusion: The combined approach validates the transition between QCD and HRG models, enhances understanding of transport properties at finite μ_B, and underscores the necessity of higher-order perturbative terms for accurate predictions.

title: Shells and bubbles around compact clusters of massive stars: 3D MHD simulations
comment: 13 pages, 7 figures, author's translation, to be published in Astronomy Letters, 51, No.6 (2025)
summary: We present the results of three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (3D MHD) simulations of the plasma flow structure in the vicinity of a compact cluster of young massive stars. The cluster is considered at the evolutionary stage dominated by Wolf-Rayet stars. This stage occurs in clusters with ages of several million years, close to the onset of supernova explosions; the well-known objects Westerlund 1 and 2 are the prototypes. The collisions of powerful winds from massive stars in the cluster core, calculated as interactions of individual outflows, are accompanied by their partial thermalization and produce a collective cluster wind. The MHD dynamics of the cluster wind bubble expansion into the interstellar medium is considered, depending on the density of the surrounding medium with a uniform magnetic field. We show that when expanding into a cold neutral medium, the cluster wind is able to reshape its surrounding environment over the Wolf-Rayet star lifetime, sweeping up more than $10^4$ $M_{\odot}$ of gas in $\sim 2 \times 10^5$ yr and producing extended, thin and dense shells with an amplified magnetic field. In a cold neutral medium with a density of $\sim 20$ cm$^{-3}$ and a magnetic field of $\sim 3.5$ $μ$G, a thin shell forms around the cluster wind bubble, characterized by a cellular structure in its density and magnetic field distributions. The cellular magnetic field structure appears in parts of the shell expanding transversely to the orientation of the external magnetic field. Magnetic fields in the shell are amplified to strengths $\gtrsim 50$ $μ$G. The formation of the cellular structure is associated with the development of instabilities. The expansion of the bubble into a warm neutral interstellar medium also leads to the formation of a shell with an amplified magnetic field.

AI.tldr: 3D MHD simulations show how young massive star clusters reshape their environment via collective winds, forming dense shells with amplified magnetic fields in different interstellar mediums.
AI.motivation: To understand how young massive star clusters, dominated by Wolf-Rayet stars, interact with their surrounding interstellar medium through wind collisions and bubble expansion. The study uses Westerlund 1 and 2 as prototypes to explore environmental shaping mechanisms.
AI.method: Conducted 3D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations modeling colliding stellar winds in cluster cores, calculating wind bubble expansion into cold and warm neutral mediums with varying magnetic fields. Analyzed resulting shell structures and magnetic field amplification.
AI.result: Cluster winds sweep >10^4 solar masses of gas in ~2e5 years, creating thin, dense shells with cellular structures and magnetic fields up to 50 μG in cold mediums. Similar shells form in warm mediums but with less pronounced cellular structures.
AI.conclusion: Collective stellar winds from Wolf-Rayet clusters drive significant environmental restructuring via MHD processes, important for understanding star cluster evolution and feedback effects in galaxy formation.

title: Black to white hole transition as a change of the topology of the event horizon
summary: We prove that the black to white hole transition theorized in several papers can be described as a change in the topology of the event horizon. We also show, using the theory of cobordism due to Milnor and Wallace, how to obtain the full manifold containing the transition.

AI.tldr: Papers show that black-to-white hole transitions involve event horizon topology changes and use cobordism theory to construct the full manifold.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to understand the physical mechanism behind black-to-white hole transitions, which are proposed in previous studies but lack a solid topological framework. The authors aim to provide a rigorous mathematical description using cobordism theory to validate and elaborate on these transitions.
AI.method: The method involves applying Milnor and Wallace's cobordism theory to analyze how the topology of the event horizon changes during the transition from a black hole to a white hole. This mathematical approach allows the construction of the spacetime manifold that encompasses the transition process.
AI.result: The key result is the demonstration that the black-to-white hole transition corresponds to a topological change in the event horizon's structure. Additionally, the authors successfully construct the full manifold describing this evolution using cobordism principles.
AI.conclusion: The conclusion establishes cobordism theory as a viable tool for studying black hole transitions, offering new insights into the dynamics of spacetime topology and potential observational signatures of such transitions.

title: Contact interaction treatment of the nucleon Faddeev equation
summary: Working with a symmetry-preserving treatment of a vector $\otimes$ vector contact interaction (SCI), a largely algebraic three-body Faddeev equation treatment of the nucleon bound state problem is introduced and used to deliver results for all nucleon charge and magnetisation distributions and their flavour separation. A strength of the SCI treatment is that it provides for a transparent understanding of this three-body approach to developing predictions for baryon observables. Comparisons of SCI results with predictions obtained in realistic-interaction Faddeev equation studies reveal the sensitivities of given observable to phenomena associated with the emergence of hadron mass.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a symmetry-preserving vector⊗vector contact interaction (SCI) method within a three-body Faddeev equation framework to study nucleon bound states, calculating charge and magnetisation distributions. It compares results with realistic-interaction models to highlight dependencies on hadron mass generation phenomena.
AI.motivation: To develop a transparent three-body approach for predicting baryon observables by leveraging symmetry-preserving contact interactions, thereby understanding the sensitivity of nucleon properties to hadronic phenomena.
AI.method: Symmetry-preserving vector⊗vector contact interaction (SCI) coupled with a three-body Faddeev equation treatment to solve nucleon bound states, allowing calculation of charge/magnetisation distributions and flavour separation.
AI.result: Delivers nucleon charge and magnetisation distributions, including flavour-separated components. Comparison with realistic-interaction Faddeev studies identifies how observables depend on hadron mass generation mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: SCI method offers a clear framework to interpret baryonic observables through three-body interactions, revealing critical dependencies of nucleon properties on underlying hadron mass phenomena.

title: A case for Case A: detailed look at binary black hole formation through stable mass transfer
summary: In isolated binary evolution, binary black hole (BBH) mergers are generally formed through stable mass transfer (SMT) or common envelope evolution. In recent years, the SMT channel has received significant attention due to detailed binary models showing increased mass transfer stability compared to previous studies. In this work, we perform a full zero-age-main-sequence to compact object merger analysis using detailed binary models at eight metallicities between $10^{-4}Z_\odot$ and $2Z_\odot$ to self-consistently model the population properties of BBH mergers in the SMT channel, determined their progenitor initial conditional, and investigate the binary physics governing their formation and metallicity dependence. We use the population synthesis code POSYDON to determine the population of BBH mergers from SMT. Using its extended grids of MESA binary models, we determine the essential physics in the formation of BBH mergers. SMT produces BBH mergers predominantly from systems with $P_{ZAMS}\leq10$ days. In these systems, both the initial mass transfer between two stars and the subsequent interaction between the remaining star and the first-born BH take place while the respective donor star is on the main-sequence (Case A). We find a limited contribution from wider Case B/C systems. Without a natal kick, the SMT channel does not produce BBH mergers above $Z>0.2Z_\odot$ due to orbital widening from stellar wind mass loss. The primary BH mass distribution shows a strong dependence on metallicity, while the mass ratio prefers unity independent of metallicity due to mass ratio reversal. Additionally, the $χ_{eff}$ distributions contain peaks at $χ_{eff}=0$ and ~0.15 of which the former disappears at high metallicities. A mass-scaled natal kick leave this sub-population unchanged but introduce a low-mass, unequal mass ratio sub-population that merges due to their high eccentricity.

AI.tldr: The study examines the formation of binary black hole (BBH) mergers via the stable mass transfer (SMT) channel using the POSYDON code, analyzing their properties across eight metallicities. SMT primarily forms BBHs from short-period systems (≤10 days) undergoing Case A interactions, with orbital widening limiting high-metallicity mergers without natal kicks. Primary BH masses depend strongly on metallicity, while mass ratios favor unity due to mass reversal, and χ_eff distributions show peaks that vary with metallicity.
AI.motivation: To understand the population properties and formation mechanisms of BBH mergers in the SMT channel, investigate the role of binary physics and metallicity dependence, and determine progenitor initial conditions using detailed binary models.
AI.method: Used the POSYDON population synthesis code with MESA binary model grids to simulate BBH mergers from SMT channels across metallicities between 1e-4Z_⊙ and 2Z_⊙. Analyzed initial orbital periods, case classifications (A/B/C), natal kick effects, and mass ratios to assess metallicity influences.
AI.result: SMT produces BBH mergers mainly from systems with ≤10-day orbital periods via Case A interactions. High metallicity (>0.2Z_⊙) systems without natal kicks fail to produce mergers due to orbital widening from stellar winds. Primary BH mass depends on metallicity, mass ratios prefer unity (mass reversal), and χ_eff peaks at 0 and ~0.15 ( disappearing high-Z). Natal kicks introduce low-mass, unequal mass sub-populations through eccentric mergers.
AI.conclusion: The SMT channel's effectiveness for BBH mergers is strongly metallicity-dependent, dominated by short-period Case A systems. Natal kicks significantly alter sub-populations, highlighting critical roles of stellar winds and natal kicks in shaping BBH merger properties. Mass ratio reversal explains the unity preference, while metallicity impacts primary mass and spin distributions.

title: Novel exact black hole solution in Dehnen $\left(1,4,\frac32\right)$ halo thermodynamics, photon circular motion and eikonal quasinormal modes
summary: Dehnen $(1,4,\frac32)$ dark matter halo has been proven to be a valuable model for describing the surface brightness distributions of elliptical galaxies, yet its implications for black hole spacetimes remain largely unexplored. In this work, we construct a novel exact black hole solution embedded in this Dehnen halo and investigate its physical consequences. The influence of the halo on black hole thermodynamics is analyzed through the mass function, entropy, Hawking temperature, heat capacity, and Gibbs free energy, allowing us to assess both local and global thermodynamic stability of the black hole-dark matter system. Our results show that the presence of a Dehnen-type halo not only stabilizes the otherwise thermodynamically unstable Schwarzschild black hole but also induces phase transitions. In addition, we study null geodesics to examine photon motion, the shadow radius and the optical appearance of the system. The dark matter halo modifies the effective potential, leading to observable changes in the photon sphere and the apparent size of the shadow. We also explore the instability of circular null geodesics and its relation to quasinormal modes in an eikonal limit. These findings highlight the significant role of realistic dark matter distributions in shaping both the thermodynamic behavior and the observable signatures of black holes, providing further insight into the interplay between dark matter halos and central black holes in galaxies.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an exact black hole solution within a Dehnen (1,4,3/2) dark matter halo, analyzing its thermodynamic stability and observable effects, such as phase transitions and modifications to photon motion and shadow size.
AI.motivation: To explore the unexplored implications of Dehnen dark matter halos on black hole spacetime properties, particularly thermodynamics and photon motion, which prior studies on elliptical galaxies did not address.
AI.method: Construct a novel black hole solution embedded in a Dehnen halo; analyze thermodynamic quantities like mass function, entropy, Hawking temperature, heat capacity, and Gibbs free energy. Also, study null geodesics to evaluate photon trajectories, shadow radius, and quasinormal modes in the eikonal limit.
AI.result: The Dehnen halo stabilizes Schwarzschild black holes, induces phase transitions, modifies photon sphere dynamics, and alters shadow size. These effects link dark matter distributions to observable black hole signatures and stability.
AI.conclusion: Realistic dark matter halos significantly influence black hole thermodynamics and observables, emphasizing their crucial role in understanding galaxy-central black hole interactions.

title: Constraints on light dark matter from primordial black hole evaporation at dark matter direct detection experiments
summary: Primordial black holes (PBHs) are able to produce light dark matter (DM) particles via Hawking radiation, and yield a flux of boosted DM that can be probed at underground DM direct detection experiments. We analyze both galactic and extragalactic contributions to the differential flux of light DM from PBH evaporation, and then compute the expected event rate from PBH boosted DM scattering off electrons or nuclei after taking into account the attenuation effect. Using recent data from DM direct detection experiments XENONnT, PandaX-4T and LZ, we set constraints on both DM-electron and DM-nucleus scattering cross sections, as well as the fraction of DM composed of PBHs $f_{\rm PBH}$ for $9\times10^{14}-1\times10^{16}\,\mathrm{g}$ PBHs that are not fully evaporated today. We also investigate the spectral evolution induced by Hawking evaporation throughout the evaporation and post-evaporation regimes. The constraints on the PBH mass are then extended into the $1\times10^{13}-6\times10^{14}\,\mathrm{g}$ window for fully evaporated PBHs.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the possibility of detecting light dark matter (DM) particles produced by primordial black holes (PBHs) via Hawking radiation, analyzing both galactic and extragalactic contributions to the DM flux. It uses data from XENONnT, PandaX-4T, and LZ experiments to constrain DM scattering cross sections and the PBH fraction of dark matter for PBH masses between 9×10^14 g and 1×10^16 g, as well as extending constraints to fully evaporated PBHs (1×10^13 g to 6×10^14 g).
AI.motivation: To explore the connection between PBHs and DM detection via Hawking radiation fluxes, addressing gaps in understanding PBH contributions to DM and leveraging recent experimental data for meaningful constraints.
AI.method: Calculates differential DM flux from PBH evaporation considering attenuation effects, models scattering off electrons/nuclei in detectors, and applies experimental data from XENONnT, PandaX-4T, and LZ to derive cross-section limits and PBH mass constraints.
AI.result: Sets constraints on DM-electron/nucleus scattering cross sections and the PBH fraction of DM for specific mass ranges. Extends constraints to lower masses for fully evaporated PBHs by analyzing spectral evolution across evaporation regimes.
AI.conclusion: Direct detection experiments provide viable probes of PBH-produced DM, narrowing allowed parameter spaces for PBH masses and scattering interactions. Future experiments could further test these models.

title: Finite time pseudo-rip singularity in cosmology
summary: By studying first a new decelerating sudden future singularity (SFS) universe we report finding a novel type of cosmological singularity which we dub a finite time pseudo-rip (FTPR) because unlike for a pseudo-rip, it happens in the finite future of the universe. In contrast to the new SFS model, where the expansion is decelerating before reaching the pressure singularity, the FTPR scenario is preceded by a super-accelerated phantom phase. Our claim is based on the thorough study of the energy conditions showing the violations of all of them for a FTPR, and only the dominant energy one for an SFS. Application of the so-called Raychaudhuri averaging shows that, alike within the requirement of geodesic completeness, these singularities are weak in the sense of this definition. We study the properties of the models including the behaviour of the cosmological horizons presented in the appropriate Penrose diagrams.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a new type of cosmological singularity called the Finite Time Pseudo-Rip (FTPR), which occurs in the finite future and is preceded by a super-accelerated phantom phase, differing from existing Sudden Future Singularities (SFS). It analyzes energy condition violations and uses Raychaudhuri averaging to classify these singularities as 'weak.'
AI.motivation: To identify new types of cosmological singularities and understand their properties, energy condition violations, and whether they qualify as weak singularities under Raychaudhuri averaging.
AI.method: The authors study the FTPR and SFS models through energy condition analysis, comparing their behaviors (decaying vs. super-accelerated phases), and apply Raychaudhuri averaging to assess singularity type. Penrose diagrams illustrate horizon behavior.
AI.result: FTPR violates all energy conditions, while SFS only violates the dominant energy condition. Both are classified as weak singularities via Raychaudhuri averaging. Penrose diagrams show distinct horizon dynamics for each model.
AI.conclusion: FTPR represents a novel cosmological singularity with unique precursory phases and energy violations, expanding understanding of finite-time cosmic singularities and their classification as weak under specified criteria.

title: Extraction of the pion-nucleon coupling constant using the effective-range expansion with the left-hand cut
summary: We apply the generalized effective-range expansion of Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 011903(2025), which incorporates the left-hand cut from one-pion exchange, to low-energy neutron-proton scattering in the $^1S_0$ and $^3S_1$ channels. The amplitude zero for the center-of-mass momentum near 0.35 GeV in the $^1S_0$ channel is naturally accommodated within this framework. We extract the pole position, scattering length, effective range, and the pseudoscalar pion-nucleon coupling constant $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ at different expansion orders. The low-energy parameters are stable and consistent with established values, while $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ exhibits larger uncertainties. The extraction of $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ is data-driven, relying on the analytic constraints from the left-hand cut and phase-shift data within the one-pion-exchange approximation. Despite larger uncertainties compared to high-precision extractions, the consistency with established values demonstrates that this framework can probe the left-hand-cut singularity.

AI.tldr: The paper applies the generalized effective-range expansion, including the left-hand cut from one-pion exchange, to analyze neutron-proton scattering in low-energy $^1S_0$ and $^3S_1$ channels. It extracts scattering parameters and $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$, showing consistency with known values despite higher uncertainties in the coupling constant.
AI.motivation: To investigate the role of the left-hand cut from one-pion exchange in low-energy neutron-proton scattering and accurately determine scattering parameters and the pseudoscalar pion-nucleon coupling constant $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$. The aim is to validate the framework's capability to probe left-hand-cut singularities using phase-shift data.
AI.method: The authors use the generalized effective-range expansion method described in Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 011903(2025), incorporating the left-hand cut from one-pion exchange. They analyze scattering data in $^1S_0$ and $^3S_1$ channels, extract pole positions, scattering lengths, effective ranges, and $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ at various expansion orders, relying on analytic constraints and phase-shift data within the one-pion-exchange approximation.
AI.result: The amplitude zero in the $^1S_0$ channel at ~0.35 GeV is naturally explained. Low-energy parameters (scattering length, effective range, pole positions) show stability and agreement with established values. The coupling constant $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ has larger uncertainties but remains consistent with literature. The framework successfully probes the left-hand-cut singularity despite higher uncertainties.
AI.conclusion: The methodology effectively incorporates left-hand cut effects, demonstrating viability for extracting scattering parameters and probing singularities in low-energy nucleon interactions. While $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ uncertainties highlight limitations, the consistency with known values validates the framework's utility for analyzing pion-exchange contributions in nuclear scattering.

title: Dirac Observables for Gowdy Cosmologies regular at the Big Bang
summary: Gowdy cosmologies are exact, spatially inhomogeneous solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations which describe nonlinear gravitational waves coalescing at the Big Bang singularity. With toroidal spatial sections they provenly have the Asymptotic Velocity Domination property, in that close to the Big Bang dynamical spatial gradients fade out and the dynamics is governed by a Carroll-type gravity theory. Here we construct an infinite set of Dirac observables for Gowdy cosmologies, valid off-shell, strongly, and without gauge fixing. These observables stay regular at the Big Bang and can be matched to much simpler Dirac observables of the Carroll-type gravity theory. Conversely, in an adapted foliation there is a systematic anti-Newtonian expansion (in inverse powers of the reduced Newton constant) of the full Dirac observables whose leading terms are the Carroll ones. In particular, this provides an off-shell generalization of the Asymptotic Velocity Domination property.

AI.tldr: The paper develops infinite Dirac observables for Gowdy cosmologies, showing their regularity at the Big Bang and connection to Carroll-type gravity's observables through an anti-Newtonian expansion.
AI.motivation: To understand the dynamics near the Big Bang singularity and generalize the Asymptotic Velocity Domination property off-shell.
AI.method: Constructed Dirac observables valid off-shell without gauge fixing, matched them to Carroll theory observables, and used an anti-Newtonian expansion.
AI.result: Observed regularity of observables at Big Bang and systematic link via expansion to Carroll theory, providing an off-shell generalization of AVD.
AI.conclusion: This work advances understanding of early universe dynamics and connects inhomogeneous cosmologies with effective Carroll gravity models.

title: Studying Energy-Energy Correlators in pp Collisions at the LHC with a Jet-Free Event-Topology Method
summary: We present a jet-free approach for measuring energy-energy correlators (EEC) in proton-proton (pp) collisions at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), employing an event-topology method that does not rely on explicit jet reconstruction. Using the leading charged hadron as a reference axis, the azimuthal plane is divided into Toward and Transverse regions, enabling a robust background subtraction and extending EEC measurements into the low $p_T$ regime where conventional jet-based approaches become unreliable. The method is validated through comparisons with conventional jet reconstruction results. We systematically explore the dependence of the EEC on the leading-particle transverse momentum and parton flavor. The observed scaling between the EEC peak position and the hard scale suggests that this topology-based EEC captures effectively the transition between perturbative and non-perturbative QCD regimes. Distinct differences are found between quark- and gluon-initiated events, reflecting their different color charges and radiation patterns. Extending the analysis to heavy flavor, EECs triggered by leading charm mesons exhibit a suppressed magnitude and a peak shifted toward larger angular separations relative to inclusive charged-particle triggers, providing a direct manifestation of the dead-cone effect. This jet-free EEC framework offers a simple and experimentally robust tool for studying the scale and flavor dependence of the QCD dynamics, with promising applications to proton-nucleus and heavy-ion collisions at the LHC.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a jet-free method for measuring energy-energy correlators (EEC) in pp collisions at the LHC using event-topology analysis without explicit jet reconstruction. It validates the approach by comparing with conventional methods, explores flavor and scale dependencies, and demonstrates the dead-cone effect in charm mesons, offering a robust tool for studying QCD dynamics.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of jet-based EEC measurements at low $p_T$ and provide a reliable method for studying the transition between perturbative and non-perturbative QCD regimes, as well as flavor-dependent effects.
AI.method: Uses leading charged hadron as reference axis to divide the azimuthal plane into Toward/Transverse regions for background subtraction. Measures EEC without jet reconstruction, analyzing scale dependence and parton flavor differences.
AI.result: Validated agreement with conventional methods; observed EEC peak position scaling with hard scale; distinct quark/gluon differences due to radiation patterns; charm meson triggers show dead-cone effect with suppressed magnitude and shifted peak.
AI.conclusion: The jet-free EEC framework effectively captures QCD dynamics across scales and flavors, providing a versatile experimental tool applicable beyond pp collisions to nuclear physics studies.

title: Search for the production of dark Higgs in the framework of Mono-Z$^{\prime}$ portal at the FCC-ee simulated electron-positron collisions at $\sqrt{s} = 240$ GeV
summary: In the present work, we study the possible production of the dark Higgs boson ($h_{D}$) candidates, which originated from a simplified-model scenario based on the Mono-Z$^{\prime}$ model, in association with a neutral gauge boson (Z$^{\prime}$). This study has been performed by studying events with dimuon plus missing transverse energy produced in the simulated electron-positron collisions at the foreseen Future Circular Collider in the Electron-Positron collision mode (FCC-ee), operating at 240 GeV center of mass energy and integrated luminosity of 10.8 ab$^{-1}$. In case no new physics has been discovered, we set upper limits at a 95\% confidence level on the mass of the dark Higgs.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the production of dark Higgs bosons (h_D) in association with neutral gauge bosons (Z') using simulations of electron-positron collisions at the FCC-ee collider. It sets upper mass limits for the dark Higgs under a simplified Mono-Z' model if no new physics is observed.
AI.motivation: To explore beyond the Standard Model physics, specifically the existence of a dark Higgs boson and its interaction with a Z' gauge boson within the Mono-Z' model framework.
AI.method: Simulated electron-positron collision events at 240 GeV with 10.8 ab⁻¹ luminosity at FCC-ee. Analyzed dimuon plus missing transverse energy signatures to probe dark Higgs-Z' production.
AI.result: If no new physics signals are found, the study establishes 95% CL upper limits on the mass of the dark Higgs boson.
AI.conclusion: The analysis provides constraints on dark Higgs parameters within the Mono-Z' model, aiding in future searches for beyond Standard Model phenomena at high-luminosity colliders.

title: Collectivity Signatures in High-Multiplicity pp Collisions from Hybrid Hydro+Tsallis Modeling of Pion Spectra
summary: The transverse momentum (pT) distributions up to pT = 20 GeV/c for pions produced in the ten different multiplicity classes (MCs) of symmetric pp collisions at sqrt(s) = 7 TeV have been investigated. Two distinct models, the Tsallis-Pareto type function (model) and the combined BGBW model and Tsallis-Pareto type model have been employed to fit the pT distributions via the minimum chi-square method. The combined Hydro+Tsallis model is more reliably describing the pT spectra than the Tsallis-Pareto model. The Tsallis temperature (T), non-extensivity parameter (q), normalization constant (N0), Kinetic freeze-out temperature (T0), transverse flow velocity (betaT), and (mean pT) have been extracted through the fitting procedure via the employed models. The Tsallis-Pareto model gives T, q, N0 and mean pT while Hydro+Tsallis model gives T0, betaT, T, q, N0 and mean pT. Incorporating the values of the extracted T and q the thermodynamic quantities and response functions, including energy density (epsilon), particle density (n), entropy density (s), pressure (P), specific heat at constant volume (CV), squared speed of sound (cs2), mean free path (lambda), Knudsen number (Kn), isothermal compressibility (kappaT), and expansion coefficient (alpha) have been calculated at the freeze-out stage. It has been observed that T, betaT, mean pT, N0, epsilon, n, s, P, CV, cs2, and alpha increase with increasing(decreasing) the charged particles multiplicity density dNch/deta(MCs). While T0, q, lambda, Kn, and kappaT decrease with increasing(decreasing) dNch/deta(MCs). These systematic variations in the trends of parameters might suggest the gradual transition towards collectivity and thermal equilibration in the high multiplicity pp events, possibly signalling enhanced collective dynamics and partial thermalization in small collision systems.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates pion transverse momentum distributions in high-multiplicity pp collisions at 7 TeV using two models (Tsallis-Pareto and combined Hydro+Tsallis), revealing trends in thermodynamic parameters that suggest partial thermalization and collective behavior.
AI.motivation: To explore collective dynamics and thermal equilibration in small collision systems through analysis of pT spectra in high-multiplicity pp collisions.
AI.method: Fit pT distributions of pions in multiplicity classes using Tsallis-Pareto and combined Hydro+Tsallis models via minimum chi-square method, extracting parameters like temperature, flow velocity, and thermodynamic quantities.
AI.result: Hydro+Tsallis model better describes data. Parameters such as temperature, flow velocity, and densities increase with multiplicity, while others (q, mean free path) decrease, indicating collective dynamics in high-multiplicity events.
AI.conclusion: Systematic parameter variations suggest a transition toward collectivity and thermalization in small systems, implying enhanced collective effects even in pp collisions.

title: Asymmetric dark matter from leptogenesis in type-III seesaw framework with modular $S_4$ symmetry
summary: We present a unified framework for neutrino masses, baryogenesis, and dark matter based on a modular $S_4$ symmetry combined with a type-III seesaw mechanism. All Yukawa couplings, CP phases, and flavor textures originate from a single complex modulus $τ$, whose vacuum expectation value controls both visible and dark sector dynamics. The same modular parameter fixes the neutrino mass matrix, determines the CP asymmetries driving resonant leptogenesis, and correlates the resulting baryon and dark matter abundances. A detailed numerical analysis shows that the model reproduces all neutrino oscillation data within the $3σ$ NuFIT~5.2 (2024) ranges for normal ordering, predicting $δ_{\rm CP} \simeq \pm (150^\circ-180^\circ)$, $\sum m_ν\simeq(0.06-0.08)~\mathrm{eV}$, and an effective Majorana mass $m_{ββ} \simeq (8 - 18)\times 10^{-3}~\mathrm{eV}$, testable in next-generation neutrinoless double-beta decay experiments. The same modular Yukawas yield resonantly enhanced CP asymmetries $|ε_{L,χ}| \sim 10^{-9}-10^{-6}$ at $M_Σ\sim 10^{7}~\mathrm{GeV}$, successfully generating the observed baryon asymmetry $η_B\simeq6\times10^{-10}$ and dark relic density $Ω_χh^2\simeq0.12$ without additional free parameters. The predicted correlation $Ω_χ/Ω_B\simeq5.4$ fixes the dark matter mass to $m_χ\simeq0.1-2~\mathrm{GeV}$, consistent with all current constraints. This framework therefore realizes a fully predictive baryon$-$dark matter co-genesis, where the geometry of the modular symmetry links the origin of flavor, CP violation, and the cosmic matter asymmetry.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a unified model combining neutrino masses, baryogenesis, and dark matter using $S_4$ modular symmetry and a type-III seesaw mechanism, driven by a single modulus $τ$ that controls flavor, CP violation, and cosmic matter asymmetry.
AI.motivation: To address fundamental questions in particle physics: the origin of neutrino masses, the generation of the baryon asymmetry, and the nature of dark matter, while unifying these phenomena under a single theoretical framework.
AI.method: A modular $S_4$ symmetry framework with a type-III seesaw mechanism. The complex modulus $τ$'s vacuum expectation value governs both visible and dark sector dynamics, dictating neutrino mass matrices, CP asymmetries for resonant leptogenesis, and dark matter relic density.
AI.result: The model successfully reproduces neutrino oscillation data within experimental limits, predicts specific values for CP phase, summed neutrino mass, and $m_{ββ}$, and generates the observed baryon asymmetry and dark matter density with a correlated mass ratio. Predicted dark matter mass aligns with observational constraints.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a testable, unified explanation for neutrino, baryogenesis, and dark matter phenomena via a single modulus $τ$, demonstrating that modular symmetry can link flavor, CP violation, and cosmic matter asymmetry without extra parameters.

title: Probing Direct $CP$ Violation in $Λ_b^0 \to P_c^+ h^-$ $(h=π,K)$ with Final-State Rescattering
summary: The LHCb collaboration has recently reported a measurement of the difference in direct CP asymmetries for the decays $Λ_b^0 \to J/ψ\, p \, h^-$ (with $h = K, π$), offering new experimental constraints on the decay dynamics of heavy baryons into charmonium final states. Inspired by these findings, we explore the branching ratios and direct CP violations for the decays $Λ_b^0 \to P_c^+(4312, 4440, 4457)\,h^-$ within the framework of final-state rescattering. Our analysis indicates that the branching fractions for $Λ_b^0 \to P_c^+ π^-$ lie around the $10^{-6}$ level, with the corresponding direct CP asymmetries approaching approximately $1\%$. In contrast, the direct CP violation for the decay $Λ_b^0 \to P_c^+ K^-$ is found to be very small, while its branching ratios show a strong dependence on the spin assignments of the $P_c$ states. These predictions may provide useful guidance for more precise CP measurements and amplitude analyses in the $P_c$ region in future experiments.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates branching ratios and CP violation in Λ_b^0 decays to P_c+ states using final-state rescattering, finding decay branching ratios ~1e-6 with ~1% CP asymmetries for pion channels, and weak CP violation but spin-dependent branching ratios for kaon channels.
AI.motivation: To explore CP violation effects and decay dynamics for Λ_b^0 decays involving newly observed P_c states, building on recent LHCb measurements of CP asymmetries in related charmonium final states.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis using final-state rescattering framework to calculate branching ratios and direct CP asymmetries for decays Λ_b^0 → P_c+ h^-(K,π), considering spin configurations of P_c states.
AI.result: Predicted branching ratios ~1e-6 for Λ_b→Pc+π channel with ~1% CP asymmetry; negligible CP violation for Λ_b→Pc+K but branching ratios strongly spin-dependent; provides benchmarks for future experimental studies.
AI.conclusion: These predictions offer critical guidance for experimental CP violation measurements and amplitude analyses targeting P_c resonance regions in upcoming experiments.

title: Symmetry-restoring finite counterterms of SMEFT four-fermion operator insertions at one loop
summary: Some effects induced by SMEFT operators at one loop have attracted a lot of attention in recent years, in particular, the renormalization of divergences by physical operators in single insertions of dimension-6 operators. Important non-logarithmically enhanced contributions must also be calculated. We discuss dimensional regularization in the Breitenlohner-Maison-'t Hooft-Veltman scheme. The goal here consists of determining in this scheme quantum effects in chiral theories at one loop. Namely, the determination of finite counterterms at one loop that reestablish the Slavnov-Taylor identities, which follow from gauge symmetries. These counterterms are necessary due to the presence of evanescent symmetry-breaking terms in the classical Lagrangian needed to regularize fermion propagators. We consider a technique that allows an easier calculation of such finite effects, relying on the identification of $(D-4)/(D-4)$ terms of one-loop amplitudes with an external ghost leg.
