We focus on dimension-6 four-fermion operators, identifying all finite counterterms in the Breitenlohner-Maison-'t Hooft-Veltman scheme at one loop, and as expected find no obstructions to the Slavnov-Taylor identities that cannot be cured by finite counterterms. This represents one step towards moving to higher order calculations.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the calculation of finite counterterms in the Breitenlohner-Maison-'t Hooft-Veltman (BMHV) scheme to preserve Slavnov-Taylor identities in chiral gauge theories with dimension-6 four-fermion operators at one loop. It introduces a method using external ghost legs to simplify computations, confirming no insurmountable obstructions to gauge symmetry restoration.
AI.motivation: To handle non-logarithmically enhanced contributions from SMEFT operators and ensure gauge symmetry through Slavnov-Taylor identities by properly renormalizing divergences with finite counterterms in the BMHV scheme.
AI.method: The authors use dimensional regularization in the BMHV scheme and introduce a technique involving insertion of an external ghost leg to isolate and compute finite counterterms for four-fermion operators. This identifies $(D-4)/(D-4)$ terms in one-loop amplitudes.
AI.result: All finite counterterms for dimension-6 four-fermion operators in the BMHV scheme are determined at one loop, showing no inherent obstacles to restoring Slavnov-Taylor identities that can't be resolved with these counterterms.
AI.conclusion: The study validates the BMHV scheme's applicability for renormalizing chiral gauge theories with SMEFT operators, paving the way for higher-order calculations.

title: Modern Machine Learning and Particle Physics Phenomenology at the LHC
comment: Contribution to EuCAIFCon 2025 (https://inspirehep.net/conferences/2832076?ui-citation-summary=true) Summary talk, 13 pages
summary: Modern machine learning is driving a paradigm shift in particle physics phenomenology at the Large Hadron Collider. This short review examines the transformative role of machine learning across the entire theoretical prediction pipeline, from parton-level calculations to full simulations. We discuss applications to scattering amplitude computations, phase space integration, Parton Distribution Function determination, and parameter extraction. Some critical frontiers for the field including uncertainty quantification, the role of symmetries, and interpretability are highlighted.

AI.tldr: Machine learning is revolutionizing particle physics phenomenology at the LHC by enhancing theoretical predictions across calculations and simulations, with applications in scattering amplitudes, phase space integration, PDF determination, and parameter extraction. Key challenges like uncertainty quantification and model interpretability are emphasized.
AI.motivation: Address the computational challenges in high-energy physics and improve accuracy and efficiency of theoretical predictions for LHC experiments.
AI.method: Overview of ML techniques applied across the theoretical prediction pipeline, including scattering amplitude computations, phase space integration, PDF determination, and parameter extraction.
AI.result: Demonstrates ML's effectiveness in accelerating and improving precision of phenomenological calculations, identifying critical areas like uncertainty quantification and symmetry incorporation.
AI.conclusion: ML is essential for future particle physics research, requiring interdisciplinary efforts to tackle remaining challenges for reliable LHC analyses.

title: Quantum speed limit time for bipartite entanglement in neutrino oscillations in matter with non-standard interactions
comment: v1: 25 pages, 11 figures, 3 tables. Comments are welcome
summary: In the three-flavor neutrino oscillation framework, we investigate the transition probabilities of an initial muon neutrino flavor state in the presence of non-standard interactions (NSIs) characterized by complex off-diagonal ($|ε_{αβ}|e^{iφ_{αβ}}$) and diagonal parameters ($|ε_{αα}-ε_{ββ}|$), including a CP-violating phase and a constant matter potential, under both normal (NO) and inverted mass ordering (IO) scenarios. Within these scenarios and through the lens of mode entanglement, bipartite entanglement measures such as entanglement entropy and capacity of entanglement are quantified in terms of the transition probabilities, which can be measured in neutrino oscillation experiments. Using these two bipartite entanglement measures, we further explore the quantum speed limit (QSL) time, which describes how rapidly bipartite entanglement evolves during neutrino oscillations. We illustrate our results using the baseline lengths and energies corresponding to ongoing long-baseline accelerator neutrino experiments, such as T2K, NO$ν$A, and the upcoming DUNE experiment. In the presence of a CP-violating phase and a constant matter potential, both with and without NSI effects, we compare the QSL time behavior for bipartite entanglement in neutrino oscillations for NO and IO. The most pronounced discrepancies in the QSL time for bipartite entanglement arise from the off-diagonal NSI parameter $ε_{μτ}$ across both the NO and IO scenarios. We emphasize that among all the experiments considered, NO$ν$A and DUNE exhibit a rapid suppression of bipartite entanglement in neutrino oscillations in the standard oscillation scenario with NO at the end of their baseline lengths for the corresponding best-fit value of CP-violating phase. Our results hint at a possible imprint of new physics in neutrino oscillations.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates how non-standard interactions (NSIs) affect neutrino oscillation probabilities, bipartite entanglement measures, and quantum speed limits (QSL) in neutrino experiments. It highlights significant differences in QSL times due to NSI parameters, particularly ε_{μτ}, and suggests potential new physics signatures in NOνA and DUNE experiments.
AI.motivation: To explore the impact of NSIs and CP-violating phases on neutrino oscillation dynamics, bipartite entanglement evolution, and QSL times in current and future experiments, aiming to detect deviations from standard oscillations that signal new physics.
AI.method: The study employs three-flavor neutrino oscillation equations with complex NSI parameters (off-diagonal/on-diagonal) and CP phases. Entanglement entropy and capacity are calculated from transition probabilities. QSL times are analyzed under NO/IO scenarios, using experimental parameters from T2K, NOνA, and DUNE.
AI.result: Off-diagonal ε_{μτ} NSI parameters cause the most significant discrepancies in bipartite entanglement's QSL times between NO and IO. NOνA and DUNE show rapid entanglement suppression in standard NO scenarios with best-fit CP phases, suggesting potential new physics contributions.
AI.conclusion: NSIs significantly influence neutrino oscillation dynamics and entanglement evolution timescales. Observing these effects in experiments could provide evidence for new physics beyond the Standard Model, with DUNE and NOνA being key experiments for testing these predictions.

title: Exploring Higgs EFT in $t\bar{t}hh$ at High Luminosity LHC
summary: The non-resonant production of a Higgs boson pair in association with a top-antitop quark pair ($pp\rightarrow t\bar{t}hh$) has only recently begun to be explored at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and provides a unique and largely uncharted probe of the top-Higgs sector, offering complementary sensitivity to the Higgs self-coupling and higher-dimensional interactions beyond the Standard Model. In this work, we present a detailed study of this process within the framework of Higgs Effective Field Theory (HEFT) at the High-Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC). A comparative analysis is performed using a traditional cut-based approach in the single-lepton channel and a multivariate parametric boosted decision tree method in both single-lepton and dilepton final states. We derive one- and two-parameter limits at 95\% confidence level on the HEFT couplings $δκ_λ$, $c_2$, $c_{2g}$, and $c_{tg}$. The projected bound on $δκ_λ$ is weaker than current experimental constraints from dedicated Higgs-pair measurement; however, this coupling plays a critical role in shaping the multidimensional allowed parameter space. For the remaining HEFT couplings, where no direct experimental limits currently exist, our results provide the first sensitivity projections in the $t\bar{t}hh$ channel. Overall, this study demonstrates the strong potential of the $t\bar{t}hh$ production process to probe extended Higgs and top-quark interactions beyond the Standard Model through the exploitation of the $t\bar{t}hh$ data at the HL-LHC.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the non-resonant production of a Higgs boson pair with top-antitop quarks (t-t~hh) at the HL-LHC using Higgs Effective Field Theory (HEFT). It compares analysis methods (cut-based vs. multivariate) and sets new constraints on HEFT couplings, offering first sensitivity projections for some parameters not yet constrained experimentally.
AI.motivation: To explore the under-studied t-t~hh production channel as a probe of top-Higgs interactions and Higgs self-coupling, and to assess its potential for detecting Beyond Standard Model physics via HEFT couplings.
AI.method: Performed a detailed HEFT analysis of t-t~hh process using two methods in different final states: cut-based approach in single-lepton channel and multivariate BDT in single/dilepton channels. Derived 95% CL limits on δκ_λ, c2, c2g, ctg parameters.
AI.result: Set first experimental sensitivity limits for c2, c2g, ctg couplings in t-t~hh channel. Found δκ_λ constraints weaker than dedicated Higgs-pair measurements, but critical for multidimensional parameter space. Demonstrated the channel's potential for probing Higgs-top interactions beyond SM.
AI.conclusion: The t-t~hh process provides a valuable probe of extended Higgs sectors through HL-LHC data. While δκ_λ constraints aren't as tight as specialized analyses, the method establishes crucial sensitivity for multiple HEFT parameters and highlights the importance of multidimensional coupling studies.
